Lev came with because he was a man willing to stand next to a thing that made him angry if that meant he didn’t have to stand next to it later with regret. The shelf was a mouth again, shut this time, and the borage had done what borage always tries to do and leaned in the direction of light, which meant three of its leaves had gotten burned into a little wryness where they’d brushed the metal. She touched the leaf and the plant forgave her faster than she had earned.

On the seam at shin-height, where only a person very close would see, someone had pasted a compass rose cut out of a cereal box and painted its points with some chemical green that held onto light too long after sunset. It wasn’t just cute, it wasn’t just a joke. The points had been sharpened until they might cut your finger if you were stupid enough to touch them hard, and in the center, where any mapmaker would have put their pretty insignia, there was a small circle in silver marker with a cross through it. The cross drifted exactly a hair off true if she held it up against the sky and the old radar tower’s ghost of a line. It was a message that knew its audience and wanted her to know that knowing.

They stood there until the cold pushed up their pant legs and made itself a citizen of their bones. Lev said he had a thermos and lied, because what he had was a bottle, and they shared it and talked about herring and about how ducks sometimes end up with fishhooks in their feet and will peck at your hands when you hold them anyway because that’s just what panic does with kindness. She told him her father’s story about jars that collect the wrong kind of rain and he told her about a storm in ‘98 that had pushed boats into places you could only reach on foot and left rope in trees so high the rope had become evidence that folly could, in fact, perch. When they were done they left the borage to do the work of being alive under poor conditions, and they let the compass rose sit and gather wet until the green started its little ghost trick of saving daylight longer than it had a right to.

Havel’s message came after midnight and pretended it wasn’t midnight with a lack of apology that almost managed to be respect. They had pulled fingerprints out of the grime and some matched the name they had chased all afternoon, the boy who had changed his name and then his occupation and then his shape. They had found metal shavings and pine cleaner and a boot print that belonged to a man who was not Brendan and who might be Brendan’s supplier or his priest. They had found a set of braces with grease that didn’t belong to any machine in the normal world, and a composition in the grease of animal fat and something you could buy in a hardware store if you asked the wrong person the right way. They had taken the map and he had asked whether she wanted to see it again, and she had said no, because she didn’t need the pins when she had the smell and the hum stored in the place on her tongue where bitterness sweetens if you hold it long enough.

He signed off with a request made like a statement. Don’t be alone. She told him she would try in the same way you tell a storm you will be inside at five, and as if the world wanted to make a liar of both of them the blog woke.

It didn’t announce itself with a trumpet. It arrived like mold arrives, quietly and where you have been blind. The words had their usual cut and their handsome cruelty and he had found a new metaphor to grind his teeth on, gravity traded in for magnetism like a boy with no humor trades in one dartboard for another. He said that people who raised candles were the kinds of people who would raise their own dead if they could and that he preferred them to stand with their soft cups of fire so he could know where to step, and buried down where only a person looking for a root would find it was a line: there are rivers that forget where they were supposed to go and there are braids that never make hair. He loved to taste his own clever and he would over-salt if you let him, and she licked the sentence and got coastal silt and old snowmelt and the particular pale dust of a certain river not twenty minutes upstream from town.

The Knik braided like an argument and shifted its mind like a woman who has decided the casserole can burn because the story she is hearing is better than the meal. People went to stand on its banks in summer to remember that big things are allowed to be uncertain, and they brought their trucks to the little scarred landings to pretend their machines were the equal of water if you gave them big enough tires. There was a spot where the current forgot itself and eddied into a quiet that made mosquitoes drunk and boys think about throwing rocks they might later tell stories about, and there was an old culvert in that spot that the borough had meant to replace five budgets ago and had instead put on a sheet called Future with a capital F. Her boots knew it. Her dog-eared tide card did not apply there but her finger knew where to put itself on the map anyway, and the prickle in her arms said he was going to stage something in a place the water could not quite reach and would keep trying to reach until it remembered how.

Olia was snoring in the little room with the quilts because she had refused to leave Lady to her stubborn and her roosters and because she understood that being a good neighbor is a skill more rare than blue eggs. Lady stood at the threshold of that room long enough to let the sound of someone else breathing rearrange her molecules, and then she put a note under the sugar jar in case notes changed the world when you weren’t looking. Lev didn’t look at his phone at midnight as a rule, which meant she had to trust him to taste morning and find her if morning asked, and she put her hands on her steering wheel like old women put hands on rosaries and left before the sky could decide what color it wanted to be today.

The riverlands were their own country even if the borough tried to govern them. Willows at shin height rattled like discomfort when trucks pushed through, and the rocks in the bars moved a little when you stood on them as if they were still considering whether to go along with this solid experiment. Mosquitoes came in a cloud that would make an atheist beg for a small god that only managed pests. She parked where the road pretended it should stop and walked the rest, her pack on, the fishing knife in the place she had decided it could be reached with dignity and not desperation. Ravens had less to say here because the river’s voice was both louder and more distracted. Her boots sank half an inch each step and then gave it back with a sigh. She thought of Rhea and her granola bars and her insistence that people can be announced by what they take from shelves, and she wondered what Brendan chose when hunger had nothing to do with it.

He had written because he liked the turn of his own wrist, but he also wrote because he was a coward of the old school who believed that telling someone where to be made him a god. If he was coming to this place, he had been here before and had found a way to make it his without looking like it was his, and a river is no one’s. That made this the most dangerous place he had chosen yet because he couldn’t fix the elements to his liking and that meant his hunger would be louder than his control. She found the culvert and the way it lifted away from the earth like a bad tooth food has found its way under, and there were prints not of his feet around it but of tires, the big-knobbed sort she had seen in parking lots where men clattered in on Saturdays and believed someone wanted to see their trucks, and then under that she saw the actual thing she had come for and had hoped not to see.

It was the middle print that gave it away, and she crouched like she might be telling a child something at their eye level and made the world smaller with her body so her eyes could be larger. Barefoot again. Toes that had been trained into their trick, the pads wide and flat like a hand that has picked raspberries all season and learned the exact pressure that bursts fruit and the pressure that keeps it whole. Beside the print, a scrape of metal had carved lines into the mud with a carelessness that still managed to spell out use. He had brought his brace here and set it down at least twice, one angle for boast and one for work. There was a mark on the lip of the culvert that suggested someone had lain on their back and slid under into the space where water has its own sovereignty in shoulder seasons.

She looked under. The flashlight made the culvert a throat and the glare on the far end was a tooth, and the breath the river pushed through carried the sweetish stink of something left and not loved. She played the light in a clean circle, left, right, and her heart added a few more beats to its life’s tally because eyes reflect and sometimes what they reflect kills you. No eyes. A sack. A shape. A careful arrangement of tools that wanted to be read as anything but what they were. She didn’t go in because this was where Havel’s category of men would be useful, and she was tired enough not to need the proof of being brave to keep herself knowing the difference between what she could and what she couldn’t.

Instead she stepped back and took in the place like a map wants to be taken. The bank on the other side had been undercut in the exact way teenagers like to sit under with a cigarette and a promise, and there was an alder with a flare at its base where the flood years had gnawed at it and been told no. Above that there was an old tire swing somebody had cut free and forgotten to take home, so it went on swinging in its black idiocy whenever wind thought it was a good time to practice persistence. The sentence in the blog about braids made a quietly smug noise at the back of her ear and she let it sit there and itch. He had wanted her here. He had counted on her looking the way she looked, seeing the print and the scrape and the forgetfulness of the river and believing those were enough. That meant there was something else, something one step to the left of the obvious.

The right smells found her when she gave up for a moment on being smarter than she was. There was the water, of course, always water, always that glacier tongue over stone, and the mud, and the rank of alder’s green asking to be forgiven for being so quick to come back after we cut it, but under that was a linen smell, the sort of manufactured clean you get off a hotel room if you breathe through the pillowcase, and threaded through that the high, thin metal stink of a battery gone a day past safe. She tilted her head until the smell had a direction and she followed it like a woman follows smoke not because she wants to find the fire but because she understands the logic of houses.

A little dead-end track vanished into the willows where no one in a truck had any business to fit, and someone with more ambition than sense had trimmed branches by hand to make a lane a man could pass with a shoulder pack and a burden. She passed with her breath tight and her step sure because there was no other way through, and then there was a cutbank with a ladder made of two-by-fours hammered into the dirt itself. He had made this. He had given himself steps where the river wanted him to slide. He had hammered his own rungs into the place that told him to earn it otherwise. At the top of the bank there was a space he had curated like a woman curates a windowsill.

The bed of an old truck sat sunk in the dirt, its tailgate off and leaned against a log like a man sitting watching the river keep trying. On the tailgate was laid out a cloth that had been clean enough to act as a prayer somewhere else and here was an altar to intention. The braces, another set, the smaller jack, a flexible cable that had the shine of something oiled and the bends of something used in anger, blue gloves pulled back on themselves like jellyfish, a simple cotton shirt folded with a soldier’s accuracy and weighted by a stone. He had brought tenderness to his cruelty and laid it around like laurels, and Lady, who had seen men lay their favorite tool on velvet in the back of a truck when they thought the tool had earned a night off, felt her stomach go into a slow, quiet boil that had nothing to do with fear and everything to do with having met enough men to know Old Testament when you saw it.

She should have left then and gone to Havel and said sentences that held nouns he could write down and use to build a case. She stayed long enough to set the tiniest trap, because she was a gardener and if she could not help herself by planting then she would help herself by rigging a line. The flagging tape she had left at the door she tied here in a tiny bow at the edge of the cloth where the fold shadow hid it until someone lifted the shirt. She set three of her nails into the wood of the tailgate so that when weight shifted just right the nails would roll and click and tell her, if she were close enough, that timing had never been a gift you leave on a table. Then she stepped down the dirt ladder and the two-by-fours gave politely and took her weight into themselves like good bones do, and she walked back to her truck with her shoulders doing the trick of hiding what her heart thought.

She had gone barely a mile toward home when the phone bit her leg with the insistence of something you’d be a fool to ignore. Havel, short words again, because short words are what men make when the world is trying to split. At the river, he said. Don’t go back in. She told him she hadn’t and meant it and told him where to find the ladder and the tailgate and chickweed and willow and the smell of someone who wants clean so badly he will stain his own hands in the name of it. He didn’t like the small trap. He liked it for its possibility and he didn’t like it because he would have to explain it to someone with a necktie, and she did not have time to parse his discomfort into categories she could take pride in. She made the left past the big spruce that had survived being struck twice by a bored god and went home to find the rooster on her porch like a critic willing to take questions after the show.

Olia was awake and making coffee that tasted like a campsite, and when Lady came in with river smell on her boots and blog itch in her jaw, Olia poured without saying anything and then said everything with one sentence. You went, she said, and Lady said she had and Olia nodded like that was the weather and the weather was not something you throw a chair at. They sat while the clock insisted on marking minutes that were all the same to a river and different to a person in love with their seconds, and when the radio finally bled news through the static it did that peculiar good-citizen thing of telling the parts of the story that could be read at dinner without anyone putting their fork down.

The blog went again and this time the sentence came at the top as if he had decided being coy was small in the face of so much possible attention. He wrote: do you still think dirt can save a thing that wants to be clean. He attached a photo taken from inside the culvert looking out, the world outside a bright circle and the edges inside full of darkness he wanted to believe was sophistication. In the left bottom of the frame, if you had seen what you needed to see to know the shape of such a place, was the edge of cloth, and in the right top corner a small shock of pink you could miss if you didn’t love trees being tagged. He had lifted the shirt. He had heard the nails. Or he hadn’t and his phone, on some newness, had decided to bless her with knowing in a way that made her wish for less information for the first time in a day.

Havel called as if someone had told him he could spend a minute on a person and he had picked which person with more thought than he liked to have to show. They found the culvert. They found the shoulder of a man who had wronged a lot of people in small ways and was the sort of wrong that can be redeemed by good luck and time and who had been granted neither. They found the tailgate and the shirt and the braces and the battery and a simple, disgusting little trick of a snare set not for deer or ducks but for hands. He said two of his men had bled from the right places and none from the wrong and that he had had to break up a fight between a boy who had been too eager and a man who had been too cautious and that the fight made him tired in his bones.

“He’s not the river,” Havel said, and the sentence would have been easy if it hadn’t sounded like a prayer falling down stairs. “He thinks he is. He thinks he gave it rules and it obeyed. He’s just a man who learned to read a tide table and a tide chart and a blog comment thread and believes he’s a god because he can read his own handwriting.”

Lady stood at the sink and let the water run and thought about how long you have to run water to clear whatever has sat in a pipe all night, and she listened to the stream get colder and then find its heart again, and she decided that she would not answer the blog and not because Rhea would approve and not because Havel would sleep easier but because she had finally found the point at which her attention was the meat he wanted. She would starve him of that one thing. She would give him the public attention he had invited law to bring and she would keep the private out of his mouth.

Night followed day with its ridiculous northern reluctance and it brought rain, real rain, not the mutter the sky sometimes offers as a threat. It soaked the cucumbers in a way that made Olia put a second blanket on her bed before she fell into it and it made the ravens look like contrary priests in slick black robes in Lady’s birches. The roof clattered the way roofs do when they remember being hammered into being by men who thought about winter while standing in summer. Somewhere a moose remembered the taste of kale and took a step and then another and then changed its mind because storms press against even the most exquisite appetite. Lady stretched out in her bed and let the sound of water make a boundary and thought about the borage taking rain by the door in the rock, one thirsty thing drinking while a bad thing slept.

She woke to a sound you do not hear often if you live where she did—a helicopter holding its place in wet sky with a temper. It went past toward the point and she hoped, against what she knew, that it was not a show. Her phone made its little insect song and this time it was Lev, words spelled all correct as if he had handed them to a daughter to polish first. They put men on the shelf and men in the throat and came out with no one but themselves. Your plant is a sailor now. He included a picture from too far off to be of any use and it made her smile anyway, the little square of green-wet on gray and the tape a limp tongue against rock. He said the hum was gone and that he could hear himself think for the first time in days and that he did not like that either because thinking is where men get hurt when their hands are not doing anything.

The day went forward on three legs and refused to fall. Rhea demanded she eat something with protein over the phone and Olia delivered that demand in the kitchen with a fork like a weapon and Lady complied with a mutiny of eggs. Havel sent a picture of the notebook page he had gotten the lab to scan at his insistence and she read the tidy blocky grid of dates and places and first names and single words like red and clean and slow and the way he had written her name once and then crossed it out with a line that pressed so hard the page had torn. The rip ran wrong direction if you were a man used to right-handed power, and she saw in it something she could use and she didn’t know yet what.

By afternoon the rain had done its work and had moved on to let wind dry what wind liked to dry, and she stood in her doorway like a woman trying to remember whether she had told her child not to put their hand on the stove fifteen minutes ago or if she was only now about to. The rooster stepped out, considered the yard, and then changed his mind and went back in like a man who had gone to town without pants. The blog did not post and that was its own sermon. She would keep her promise to herself and let her silence be the fence it needed to be, and she hung her moose-patch cap by the mudroom door as if she were someone capable of putting a thing down and leaving it there.

Toward evening, which in June is a complicated direction, a truck she did not recognize turned up her road and came as far as the gate and stopped. She watched through the kitchen window with the respect a person gives a vehicle that might hold something bad or something uninteresting and often holds both, and when the passenger door opened and a woman she did not know swung her legs down she made herself still because stillness is the only thing that can look like friendliness and caution at the same time. The woman had a hood up against the leftover spit of rain and under the hood a face with that particular set Lady recognized from waiting rooms and vigils and roadsides with taped-up crosses. She had meant to be somewhere else today and had been detoured by bad news and worse possibilities and now she was choosing to stand on a stranger’s gravel because she had decided motion was the only way to keep from coming apart.

“Lady Palov,” the woman said, louder than she had to, like the wind owed her an acoustic favor. “I am Dr. Clement’s sister.” She looked like the sort of person you would hand your keys to without a second thought and the sort of person who could carry a inexpressible damn heavy thing without telling anyone her back hurt. She was not crying because she had spent her tears in the riot of terrifying days and was going to send herself an invoice later for all the fluid she had lost to grief and rage. “They told me—well, they told me everything and nothing. They said you had been near the place where maybe he sits and thinks he’s a weather system. They said you plant things. I hate the thought of someone planting the ride to my brother’s last breath and I hate how little I can do that is not screaming. I brought you—this.” She lifted a paper bag like groceries and pulled out a mason jar with a thin elastic of string around the neck and in it were seeds and a label in a steady hand that read simply: bees, blue.

Lady took the jar as if it might kick. They were borage, of course they were, blue stars waiting for a crack in the ground, this woman’s offering and grief and request all in one. Behind the woman, the ravens sat in the willow like comment, and beyond them, past fence and road and ditch and the place where trucks go by on their way to somewhere else, the world kept up its work of being itself in spite of men who wanted to crush and clean and call it correction. Lady set the jar on the table next to the sugar where her note sat under its small glass lightness and she said that she was sorry in a voice that carried little and meant a lot.

“When this is done,” she said, because she believed in after even when after is a kind of lie you have to tell to get to sleep, “we’ll put a row of these where the wind knocks and the cold cuts, and I will bring you over and make you tea, and we will watch bees lose their minds on blue. Until then, one thing at a time.” The woman’s hands unclenched and then clenched and she nodded like a pilot making a landing for which there is no easy air.

That night Lady put the jar of seeds on the sill and the rooster did not comment and the wind put its shoulder to the corner of the house where the logs always creak like they’re talking to each other about politics. She looked toward where the river braided itself into indecision and toward the point where machines insisted on humming and then did not, and she lay down with her body making a promise her mouth had already drafted. In the house, the hum was a refrigerator and an old clock. Outside, the audible world took care of itself. In the other world, in the places men had cut into rock and under roads, Brennan made himself a myth again and wrote the next sentence and chose the picture that would make it sing.

Morning would bring with it a choice about whether to follow the river to the culvert again or to go to the city and sit in the lobby of the clinic and make Rhea eat something that wasn’t a granola bar, and morning would bring a call from Lev with a story about a gull stealing someone’s hat and a remark about gravity that would outshine the killer’s. It would bring a blot of color in the ditch where the ditch-wet plant that smelled faintly of pennies had put up its tiny flags, and she would remember that flags are useless and meaningful both. For now, in the half-dark that the north confuses with night, she closed her eyes and in the dream that came without asking she was pressing seed into soil with a care that made the act a kind of speech, and each seed was a small perfect word and the row she made spelled not here, not this, not now, not you.Morning arrived not with certainty but with the soft indecision the north favored in June, a gray that could burn off or bring its own weather and never felt obliged to give you an answer first. Lady woke to the polite knock of rain on the window over her sink, the smell of coffee someone else had been kind enough to start, and the faintest metallic taste that meant her mind had been chewing on the same problems all night. She found the jar of seeds Mara had left on the table where she’d set it, the label’s careful “bees, blue” gone a little soft where steam from the kettle had curled up and breathed on it. She wanted to scatter the seeds right then, to press them into the wet soil with the urgency of a person making a ward, but the day was already full of errands she had not listed and promises nobody had asked her to make. She washed and put on the moose cap and ate two pieces of toast with the seriousness of a penitent, because Rhea’s voice lived in the house now saying protein and Lady had no desire to be scolded by a woman with a stethoscope from thirty miles away. Olia, at the stove in borrowed socks and a sweatshirt that had once belonged to an ex-boyfriend and then to every woman on the block, poured her more coffee and did not ask what the plan was because asking made people lie.

The clinic lobby in Anchorage was warmer than outside in all the right ways and one wrong one; it had that intimate pressure of a place where people have cried quietly and been told to breathe and do their best and maybe not today but soon. Rhea stood at the reception desk barking at a printer that had decided to jolt three letters off every line, hair doing its extraordinary disobedience and pen stuck behind her ear in a way that made it look like the pen had climbed there to hide. Lady dropped a paper bag on the counter, hard enough to produce the noise of sandwich, and Rhea’s face softened into something that was not quite gratitude and not quite surrender and still looked like both. They found ten minutes in a break room where a child had drawn a rabbit on the wall and no one had erased it because it had more humanity than the poster about hand washing, and they ate in the manner of people who know the day hasn’t yet shown its teeth. Mara Clement appeared in the doorway like a woman who had never once in her life asked a stranger for anything and was learning the skill under the worst circumstances; she wore a rain jacket she had borrowed from a cousin and had a sheet of paper in her hand with too many signatures to look like prayer and just enough to look like a plan. She set a second jar of borage seeds between the sugar and the stir sticks and said they were for later, for when the ground could take a row of something that didn’t mind cold and would give bees an honest job.

“You look like you slept sideways,” Rhea said to Lady, not unkindly, and then to Mara she said the thing doctors say when they have learned to be careful and still insist on being human, that she was sorry, that Dr. Clement had been a better man than the job had deserved and the job had deserved a better man than most, and that candlelight in June never looked right and she was angry that it had had to. They didn’t talk about the blog because it felt like feeding something small and voracious in the corner of the room, but the presence of it arranged the conversation anyway, made silences a little sharper and the way each woman held her shoulders a little more intentional. Lady kept seeing the line in the notebook Havel had sent her a picture of, that one clean neat stroke crossing out her name, the force of it enough to tear the paper wrong if you were left-handed and angry, and she found herself picking up the pen Rhea had used on her printer and noticing the way it sat in her own right hand, ordinary as a spoon.

Havel called from an office he didn’t like and a chair that made a squeak he distrusted, told her through a mouthful of other responsibilities that the grease signature they’d pulled off the braces had a lean-to of ingredients you couldn’t find except at a welding supply near Ship Creek that also did business in used dive gear. “It’s a hole in the wall that both the Coast Guard and boys with fantasies visit,” he said, which made Lady wince for reasons that weren’t entirely linguistic. They had men on it, he said, but if she found herself needing a coil of rope or an elbow of opinion he wouldn’t tell her no, which was either an invitation or an apology dressed as permission. She didn’t go to the welding place because that didn’t smell like her work; she went instead to the park strip where a handful of volunteers were turning the place of candles into a line of tablecloths and small tents, Saturday’s market not yet a market but a promise someone had decided not to break because the city needed something that wasn’t evidence or rumor. She helped unroll canvas and watched a man with forearms braided like rope lift a folding table with an absent gentleness that told her he had children and chose, on purpose, not to be hard.

Olia arrived with crates of jam and the ability to swear cheerfully at a T-post, and Lev appeared because anybody on a dock who wanted to be told a story had sent him here with a sack of smoked salmon and a hat the gulls had changed their mind about stealing. Rhea came with a blood pressure cuff and the insistence that she could take an hour and that if someone in scrubs called her through a phone she would let it ring once. Mara stood behind a folding table with a coffee can and a yellow pad and a photograph of her brother tacked to a corner, the picture one of those mid-laugh images that prove the person existed in more configurations than grief allows, and she wrote down names of people who wanted to help the clinic forge its grief into a scholarship or a broom. Lady let her hands learn a new pattern—clip, pull, spread, tie—and for thirty minutes the day made sense because the wind had decided to mind its manners and the world could be covered with a thin skin of ordinary.

The stall half a block down from Olia’s had a banner that read Schools Read! and under it three teenagers sat in folding chairs and took turns reading out loud into a microphone that squealed when it wanted attention like a neglected child. A girl with a haircut that would have gotten her pushed down where Lady had grown up read a poem about a river remembering itself and a boy with a voice like a hinge read a piece about gravity that made people snort in a way they didn’t recognize was joy. Lady felt the prickle of a wrong smell then, the sharp false-pine of cleaner in a shadow that had no business being scrubbed, and she moved toward it without needing to decide. The wrong smell coiled under the literacy table where the volunteers had set a crate of extra books and the microphone cords snaked like harmless snakes, and when she crouched and pulled the crate out with a flick of her fingers she saw the metal glint of something structural fixed to the underside of the table itself.

It was clever and a little crude, a brace wedged to expand when a lever arm was pulled, built to drive up against the ribs of whoever leaned their hip against the table to speak into the microphone, and if the lever had been pulled then the moment where a young man with a new haircut laughed into the mic would have become a ruin. She didn’t touch the lever because touching is a way traps talk, and instead she reached into her backpack as if she were a woman looking for a different kind of tool and took out the wire she had brought as if her hands had known one part of the day would remember the point. She fed the wire into the hinge like a surgeon reminding flesh how to lie down and then she tied the lever off to a table leg so any tug would be nothing more than a line singing against wood. Olia’s voice floated over her head, all jam and sarcasm, asking if anyone was selling anything that tasted less respectable, and in the pocket of that noise Lady motioned a man in a vest over and spoke in a voice so plain it made even obvious things feel palatable, told him to call Havel and to get a look under every single piece of furniture within shouting distance.

The young man with the new haircut finished his piece and sat down and smiled like anyone would smile after surviving five minutes with a bad microphone and a worse wind, and Lady stood up and kept her face as neutral as winter. Havel arrived with half his mouth in a frown and the other half already talking into a radio, and he bent under the table with a skill born of years of crawling into places his body didn’t enjoy. Men in coveralls moved through the park like guilt and lifted and tipped and peered, and every so often one would straighten with an object in his hand that wanted another name than the one it had been given at the welding shop. Under one bench where an old woman had been making bracelets for a price that filled no one’s pocket was a little battery fixed to a bracket made of thrift-store brass and a bolt, the sort of small thought that makes surgeons swear into their masks.

True North posted in that breath between finding and removing and the body deciding it needed to shiver. He put up a photograph of the tailgate chiffon and the corners of his braces like he wanted to remind anyone paying attention that the stage was his and he’d chosen a fine cloth. He wrote about correction again and about softness, took the risk of addressing her without the shield of the world by mentioning blue stars and bees, and in the middle of a sentence that tried very hard to be a sermon he slipped and called the market a fair and the territory of men who play with weight. It was a word nobody here used for the Saturday business, and it told Lady the man who wrote hadn’t grown up with a certain kind of woman selling rhubarb out of Tupperware in the wind. She put her phone face down on Olia’s stack of singles and weighed it with a jar of raspberry, and Olia smacked her wrist and said if she broke the jam with her technology she’d have to eat it with her hands.

The day burned off its gray and put on its clean blue and people went on buying honey and dog biscuits with more earnestness than anybody required of them, and when the last table was folded and someone who had volunteered to collect the trash forgot three bags by the tree near the path, Lady picked them up because that’s how neighborhoods end up decent. Havel walked with her as far as the Dumpster because sometimes a man in a badge understands that taking out the trash is the only thing that hooks a day back into its proper hinge. He told her they’d traced the braces to the shop by Ship Creek as expected, that a clerk had remembered a man with quiet hands and a jacket too big for him paying in cash and looking at the oxygen tanks like he was watching a dog dream. The clerk had called him sir and then had called the hot line when the news made his stomach turn an hour later, and Havel had written sir in his notes with a circle that meant men need to decide what they’re willing to call other men and when. They dumped the trash and the lids clanged and a gull laughed because gulls always laugh when the wrong noises interrupt their day.

Back home the rain had finished leaving polite and the cucumbers had forgiven everything. Mara’s second jar of seeds waited like a solution small enough to hold, and Lady took it outside and made a row at the edge of the garden where wind makes a point of being cruel in the morning. She broke the soil with the end of a trowel she loved for the way the wood had learned her grip, her body easing into the old ceremony of press and cover and pat as if she were laying coins over a sleeping friend’s eyes, and she spoke in the way a woman speaks when no one needs to hear her to know she means it. Olia came and sat on the stoop with a mug and told a story about Nik trying to make the rooster wear a harness so he could walk him past the neighbor’s dog like a conqueror, and Lady laughed because even the world they were in didn’t get to take away the ridiculous.

Evening’s first stiffness carried a smell she recognized not as pine or wet or grilled meat but as electricity thinking about being a storm, and she took that as counsel to check again the little rituals she’d made, the latches on the greenhouse, the wire she’d rigged on an old gate so it would sing if a big animal tried curiosity. The blog did not post and she refused to help it by conjuring words for it to salivate over, and when she did allow herself to look through earlier posts she did it with the discipline of a woman sharpening a knife and then putting it back in its place. She found an old line about compasses printed on the inside lid of a shoe box and knew where he had cut that cereal rose, imagined the pair of scissors held in a hand that wanted to be delicate and had taught itself to imitate. When the dogs down the way declared a car and then changed their minds, she set the kettle on and listened to how the house sounded very much like a house that could be trusted, because old wood has no gift for deception and tea kettles are accountable in a way men have to practice.

The knock came with the embarrassment of someone who hadn’t meant to disturb a woman at her stove and had done it anyway, and when she opened the door Lev stood there with his cap in his hands and a face that would have been rueful if it weren’t preoccupied with being angry. He had a padded envelope he’d picked up from his box because the brown had her name and address hand-lettered in a tidy square that had made his stomach do a thing he didn’t like, and he set it on the table and stood well away from it like he was obeying a commandment no one had written. Lady felt the weight with her hands first, that learned scale of heft as message, and then tilted it slightly and smelled metal and dust and the faint, smug scent of something wiped down. She took a knife and slid it under the flap and slit without making a performance and tipped the contents into a bowl so the envelope itself wouldn’t take on the power of an omen.

The compass rose had been cut out of embroidered denim that had once been someone’s jacket, points stitched in a thread that did, in fact, hold onto light with the greed of glow paint, and the edges of the points had been shaved sharp with a scalpel or obsessive patience. It lay there pretty in a way that was trying too hard to be the kind of pretty you throw out later and then miss, and in its center was a circle of mirror she could tell had been broken off a bigger piece, the backing scratched with a small X. There was a pinch of salt in the bottom of the envelope, loose like an accident you were meant to notice, and a folded slip of paper so crisp she knew it had been cut from a ream meant for newsletters or threats. He had written in the block hand again, the neatness of a man who learned to get approval by never leaving a flourish, and he had left a sentence that was less clever than he thought: North doesn’t love you back. Under it, in smaller letters as if he had realized he’d gotten too poetic and needed to drag himself back to practical, he had printed a time and a name that made Lev suck air between his teeth. Knik Arm overlook, he had written. Dawn.

She had thought her stomach could not shrink further in her body without becoming mean. It did. Lev swore eloquently and then did that thing men who have spent their lives on water do when asked to be present on land for a different kind of task, which is to do the small tidy thing that will be helpful for six minutes and then ask you how many of those he can chain together into a day. “He likes stages,” Lev said after he had calmed the part of himself that hated acknowledging the theatrical urge in others. “And he likes a big sky over his head so his words sound like they matter. You going.”

“I don’t know yet,” she said, because she was trying to tell the truth more consistently than was polite and because showy refusals only made men like the one who had written that note lean in. “He wants me to be at the overlook because then I will be seen being at the overlook. He wants to be filmed if he gets caught and he wants to be thought brave if he doesn’t. Havel will be there; he will bring men who can count and men who can run and men who have practiced not shooting if they can help it. If I go, I go as a hand that can turn a small thing at a small moment, not as his opposite number in some bad myth.”

Lev’s mouth made a shape as if to say the old words about bait and traps and smarter critters, and instead he said that he would be at the lower pullout at a time no good person should see their own breath, and that he would bring coffee that could put hair on a baby’s chest, and that if she needed to get out between something and the river he would be there to lay his boat like a coin under her foot. She packed the compass rose back into the envelope with two fingers like a woman handling a dead bee and put the thing under a heavy book that had once taught her how to build a hoop house without bankrupting herself and now would serve as good honest weight. The salt she poured into her palm and took outside and shook onto the ground where the walkway met the driveway because there was a meanness in her that wanted to answer a symbol with a ritual and because she did not much like the idea of walking the grit into the seams of her floorboards.

Sleep was a play acting as radio static and she drifted in and out of a dream where she was planting nails instead of seeds and the row spelled out a warning no one could read. The rooster had the nerve to keep his mouth shut until four and then remembered who he was and made noise, and she got up and rinsed her face and took the thermos and set out while the sky was still doing its difficult trick of becoming day without committing to it. The overlook waited with signs about belugas nobody ever saw when they wanted to and a railing somebody had painted with a color that had looked brave in the hardware store and pleading out here, and the wind came off the mud and water with a fine galley of bad smells and good. Havel stood with a pair of binoculars Levs’ had sneered at once and a face that had learned a little about resting since yesterday, and his men had the look men get when they have been told to hold still at dawn, which is to say their bodies were lying and their hands kept remembering small motions and then sitting on those.

“You don’t go to him,” Havel said to Lady in a voice that had practiced being quiet enough to carry only to the correct ears. “You let him be a man walking into a place with his choices making a noise, and you be a woman who hears noises. If he’s playing a game with words at you, you don’t give him nouns. You nod at verbs and make them stumble.” It was a ridiculous plan and a good one because it acknowledged the thinness of the thing they were doing and the largeness of the person who had decided to make the world into a stage where he could be terrible and alive at the same time. Lev was where he had promised, his truck idling gently as if trying not to wake the poor souls bundled under quilts and regrets in houses along the arm, and when he raised a hand in a motion that looked like a man adjusting his hat Lady felt the clean click of a signal made by friends who have not had the practice and yet know what their hands need to do.

He came not on foot, which surprised nobody, and not in a truck anybody could identify later, which angered Havel in its correctness. He came on a bicycle with oversized tires that made the mud its accomplice, jacket still two sizes too big, hair hiding the work that living had asked it to do, hands in his sleeves not because of cold but because he had learned that people will forgive a man’s hands anything if he gives them time to make a story about the rest of him. He rode up to the overlook as if he had been doing it every day as a man who cares about his lungs, laid the bicycle down carefully as if it were a dog asked to wait, and looked at the sign about belugas like a man choosing what to say to a child who has asked a fair question and used an unfair tone. He saw Lady and smiled with an intimacy that would have been obscene if it had had any real understanding in it.

“You brought a crowd,” he said, and his voice did the boy thing again, the edges our whole polite world rubs off men who have to keep their licenses renewed and their lights paid. “I would have chosen a quieter place if I wanted to whisper.”

“You don’t whisper,” Lady said, and the edge of his smile told her she had been right to keep her words low and uninteresting, because he had wanted a sentence he could step into and make into a pretext for a speech. He reached into his sleeve and pulled his hand free, and there they were, those hands she had tried for a week now not to make into myth, the nails with their softened edges and strange thickness, the webbing of a life lived at the ends of fingers, the hint of something hard under the skin that had no place there if we were made to fit polite. He set his palm flat on the sign as if to push into the idea of circle of life until it gave up on itself and looked foolish.

“I thought you’d bring me something alive,” he said, weary now with the tone of the person who expects someone else to do their homework and then complains when the answers are wrong, and she gestured toward the estuary with its countless small birds and its living mud and did not smile, because smiles are sometimes a trap you set for yourself. His eyes did a little darting trick men’s eyes do when they are trying to confirm their power without admitting they need confirmation, and when those eyes caught the semi-circle of not-police he did not smile wider; the theatrical instinct was too practiced for that, and instead he gave a small shrug as if to concede that this was the audience his pride deserved.

He talked, because of course he did, and he said the words he had already written in his blog but let them be colder in the air, less crafted, less safe with their practice. He spoke about correction, about the waste of softness, about the sickness that comes from people apologizing to each other for wanting the wrong things. He spoke about North like it was a person who had called him once and said a secret into his ear, and he spoke about being clean, and Lady felt her face go still because the only way to lean a day back toward sanity sometimes is to refuse to let it see your eyebrows move. Havel shifted in a way that made the men around him shift too, a small animal motion that said two more sentences and then we stop this with more than talk, and Brendan’s mouth went into a bow meant to draw and let fly.

It was Lev who ended it, and Lady would never stop loving him for it. He coughed in the way old fishermen cough when they want to announce a weather change and then said, very clearly and as if he were telling a child not to pet a dog, “You’re boring.” The word slid over the wet rail and landed at Brendan’s feet like a fish nobody wanted, flapping, and the man who had thought himself a weather system blinked because weather is never bored and he had never once in his life imagined he could be. Boredom unmade him more effectively than any slur about monsters or any polite slicing up of his rhetoric could have, and in the breath where the sentence he had prepared and the sentence he needed to say next collided, Havel moved.

The men who had been practicing not to be a movie stepped forward in their unsticky boots and put hands in places that had been explained and practiced a hundred times, hands and elbows and the weight a decent body can carry into its choice. Brendan tried to go to ground in the way of men who believe the earth would prefer them, and the men in vests were not unkind but they were done with listening. He had a blade somewhere and never got to it because a fabric seam he had counted on betrayed him in a way that made him look briefly, blessedly, like anyone else in a jacket that does not fit. He spat something, not words, and a gull cried a laugh that made Lady love gulls more than they deserved. When they got him on his feet his hands had bloody half-moons in them where his nails had reminded him of what he had made himself into, and he looked not at the river or the sky or Havel but at Lady, because he had given her that role in his head and had not yet learned she refused to perform. She tilted her head and might have nodded almost nothing at a man who had confused correction with cruelty and thought the world owed him applause. If there was pity in her, it was red and clean and had nothing to do with forgiveness.

Paperwork happened, because even in the north where you can drive until the road forgets it is a road, the world insists on receipts. Havel handed Brendan over to other men with other jobs and made notes that would be read into a microphone later with a storybook smile that would irritate the part of him that hates theater, and he came back to stand by Lady and Lev while the wind took the smell of an undone storm and made it its own. “Good work,” he said to no one and everyone, and then because that was too much like an award he added, “Now we hold the seams until the rest is done.” Lev spat into the gravel with the relief of a man who has been allowed to call something stupid and has been heard.

They drove home with the tiredness that follows adrenaline like a dog and found that Mara had already been to Lady’s place and left a note on the jar of seeds that said, in a hand that had clearly not been made by this business, garden soon, and the rooster had decided adolescence again and tried to fight his reflection in the window until Olia had scolded him like a toddler. The blog, when Lady allowed herself the grit to look, had put up nothing new, and if someone else posted as a friend of the friends of the author, the voice put on the jacket of a thousand other men and meant less than the note on the seeds. Lady went out with the trowel and made a second row, because two lines look more like a plan than one, and she pressed each seed down with the pad of her finger in the way you do when you’re putting small lives into cold ground and trusting what you can’t see.

Night came as far as night could in June and sat down at the edge of the yard like a man who will not come in and will not leave, and Lady lay down and let the sounds the house made draw her into a rest that looked like sleep even if it was only the arm around it. In the dream she had then, she went to the door in the rock and found it full of bees, all of them delighted with their work, and behind them a hum that was clean and had no quarrel with her bones, and that hum moved in her chest when she woke and found that the window had gone gray with a weather that had decided to be generous one more day. She poured coffee and drank it by the sink because sometimes cups are too slow, and then she found her list by the salt cellar and added a line that had waited too long to be written: begin again.The days after a monster is taken do not behave. They slip their collars and run down side streets and into alleys where the light cannot organize them, and you stand at your sink with your coffee and your hands and realize you are going to have to shepherd them with nothing but your voice. Lady felt that immediately. The morning after the overlook brought a sky that had trouble deciding whether it wanted to be a ceiling or a sheet, and the garden took that confusion as permission to grow in fits. She walked the rows with a mug warming her fingers and her boots dampening at the toes and told herself out loud that garlic scapes teach you timing, and that timing was going to be asked of her again. The rooster had forgiven the men with vests as if his brain knew how to file it under weather, and the cucumbers had slept well enough under rain that they would pretend nothing had ever tried to harm them. On the table inside, the jar of borage seeds waited like a promise made by someone who loved her brother and wanted the ground itself to acknowledge him.

Havel called with a voice that had practiced apologizing and now refused to do it more than once. They had Brendan in a place with keys and fluorescent lights; he had an attorney with the right kind of hair and the wrong kind of face; he had said nothing for the first hour and then said a few things that would sound good in a podcast and not so good later. Lady listened and heard the exhaustion dragging at the bottoms of the words, the way a tide pulls a little sand with it every time it moves. There was an arraignment scheduled, there was a probable cause hearing someone would make theatrical, there were men whose ties had been pressed standing in hallways pretending to be part of history. Then, with the sound of an old chair complaining faintly, Havel said it: we are not done. A boot that didn’t fit the boy’s foot had been found at the bunker, and the grease pointed toward hands that had known fabrication before they knew cruelty as a philosophy. Someone had built those braces. Someone older, or at least a different kind of patient, had taught him how to take a jack and a length of cable and give it ideas.

She stood in a courtroom anyway because there are rituals that belong to the living, and watching a man hear his name read out loud by a clerk who has practiced pronunciation is one of them. The room had the long-worn shine of places where everyone stares at the same spots on the floor while waiting for a decision, and the light through the windows tried very hard to turn court wood into church wood and failed. Brendan came in with his hands in front of him in that awkward performative way the system forces, and he wore his jacket no longer, and without it his shoulders looked borrowed less, more nakedly what they were. He looked for her and found her because he had made her an object and objects are easy to locate when you have decided they exist for your use. She held his gaze for the exact amount of time it takes for a kettle to go from almost to full, then put it down and let the rest of the room have him. Mara Clement stood two rows up, her hand on the back of a chair like it was a friend’s shoulder, and when she left after the clerk had finished their teeth-work Lady saw her stop in the corridor and inhale once like a runner taught to breathe before the hill.

The blog made an absence of itself for a day and then returned with the smugness of a scheduled post. It wasn’t his voice quite, and Lady could feel the angle like a draft under a door; the words wore his sweater and didn’t have his heat. There was a passage about corrections who are actually cowards, and tucked under it a photograph that had not been uploaded by a man who was currently signing forms into three carbonless sheets. The photograph was of a bench in a school hallway and a pair of blue shoe covers dangling like jellyfish from the lip; the frame included a cinderblock wall painted with an ocean mural and a whale a child had given eyelashes. The caption said something that wanted to be a proverb about cleanliness. She felt her jaw go hard in that unflattering way stress always made her face arrange, and she texted Havel with a link and no commentary because he would have words enough.

Ship Creek stank in the fine respectable way of places where real work and old water get up in each other’s business, and the welding supply lived in a square building that had given up on being pretty a while ago and found contentment in being indispensable. The sign was sun-faded and the bell over the door sounded like it had belonged to a bakery once, and when she walked in the air did that change it does when it decides to let you know it is holding more metal than oxygen. The walls had pegs with the sort of tools that make a person a little better and a little worse at the same time; masks gawped from hooks, hoses lazed in piles, spools of wire sat fat and smug. The man behind the counter had a face that had been sanded down by an even mix of funny stories and headaches, and he had the stance of a person who has been approached by too many men trying out the same toughness. He did not comment on her braid or on the cap; he said how can I help and meant it within the boundaries of capitalism.

She asked after a brace; she asked after modifications; she asked after cash customers with quiet hands and a way of standing that kept their elbows close like a secret. He narrowed his eyes in the way men do when they are weighing the value of their afternoon against the discomfort of being part of something real, and then he turned and gestured to a back door and asked if she could smell pine. She could, under the hot stink of an arc and the bottom-note of stale coffee. They went out onto the loading apron and he pointed at a spot where someone had tried to make a mess into an invitation. Pine cleaner had fought machine fat there and lost in long, morale-hurting streaks, and under the streaks you could see the prints of a shoe with a tread that loved its own drama and a bare print with toes splayed, faint, as if something had leaned there barefoot while waiting for a man to run a card.

“Quiet hands,” the man said, his voice an apology aimed at the earth. “Bought cable and two spools and asked after a clamp for compression that I don’t recommend to boys who have to meet OSHA. He had a friend once or twice, older, not as quiet, left hand dirty, right hand with two fingers that had stories they didn’t want to tell. Friend smelled like cigarettes where they refuse to die. Paid cash. Said—this’ll make it clean. I told him that wasn’t what we sold and he laughed like maybe he knew.”

Northern Salvage lived downriver in a yard that pretended it had rules until you asked them to show you and then they pointed at the ravens and told you the birds were in charge. Lev came because yards like that were his childhood, and he parked with his front tires aimed at the exit in a way that told every person with a certain haircut that he had learned this lesson a generation ago. The fence had flowers painted on it by someone trying to make their job more bearable; under the paint rust did its phlegmy work. Inside, old anchors leaned like men at a reunion, and lengths of chain lay coiled like something waiting for a whistle. They found the office by noise rather than by plan, an old radio playing a station dedicated to songs about trucks and heartbreak, and behind the counter a woman with a braid saltier than sea answered to Ilya like it had been given to her by a different language’s grandmother.

She did not like police or the idea of police at the salvage yard, and when Havel came striding over the aprons with his government spine she frowned with generosity. Lady let Lev do the version of hello that involves a joke about a crane and a halibut that is only funny if you understand how far boats once traveled here for what they thought they wanted. Books were produced because Ilya had found that paper always outlasted computers at a certain level of damp, and in the third log they found a name that was not a name they knew. Marsh. He had bought scrap flats and lengths of steel, he had asked after a set of dive weights, he had inquired about whether anyone around here did small custom jobs without a receipt. Ilya pointed with her chin at a shed with a tar-paper roof and a door that had been kicked into obedience so often it had gotten to like it, and Havel made a sound with his teeth that meant both here and careful.

Inside the shed the hum was human, a little generator trying to persuade an old light to behave, and the bench had that particular patina of men with a craft convincing themselves it is an art so they may forgive the harm. Weld beads ran along one corner of a brace in a stack of dimes that was left-handed if you knew that trick, and a coffee can full of spent rods found ways to look guilty. On a shelf, wrapped in paper that had once had someone’s turkey in it, lay a compass rose cut out of denim and sharpened Jeff-mad at the points; one of the points retained the tiny punctures of a machine needle where someone with a sewing machine had tried to reinforce meaning. There were cigarettes crushed into the floor dirt, filterless, and on the wall, tacked with a nail through its heart, a Sunday-school handout not from any Sunday school Lady had ever stooped into. Clean Hands, Clean Heart, it announced in a font that might forgive you if you ironed it, and below it four beatitudes someone had rewritten for the stainless and the cruel. Lev took off his cap because sometimes you do that in rooms that break your heart two kinds of ways.

Rhea told her to stop three times over the phone in three different words, and Lady took the scolding with the patience of a person who knows the advice is a poultice and will sting more at first than it will soothe. Then she went anyway because she could feel the direction of rot, and you do not let rot get a corner if you can help it. The pool in town smelled like laps and afterschool and the bottom of every summer, and the filter room had a sign on it that made its door look as if it would be grateful if anyone treated it gently. The janitor was a woman with forearms that made Lady feel the mild shame that accompanies realizing you could be better at lifting your own life, and she nodded briskly when told she had been housing something ugly and did not look surprised because public buildings are where ugliness likes to nap. Under the pipes and the blue-tiled altar to chlorination lay another device, cleaner, more refined, sized not to crush a child but to put a paramedic out of work for six months, and Havel did with two fingers what would save three lives if the day went a certain way.

Blog silence turned into a scratchy flurry and then into a voice that did not have Brendan’s grammar. The hand behind it was older, the sentences had a kind of Sunday haltingness you only get if someone taught you to write on thin paper in a basement of a church they rented for six months in the late eighties. The name at the bottom of the entry pretended to be the same because men who assist monsters enjoy the costume closet, and it proposed in a stiff way that society had been too lenient and would be corrected by the weather and the truth and a good hand. There was a phrase about masks hanging in rooms where people pretend, and Lady, who had slept once on a pile of velvet capes in the high school’s costume cupboard because she had missed a bus and the theater teacher had been kinder than she needed to be, felt her pulse trip. The traps would move to places where kindness was stored thin. She called the school and got a man who taught math and theater and who kept his keys on a belt clip as if he were afraid if he didn’t tether them they would go run away and make better choices; she told him to unlock and look, and when he did he made a sentence that wanted to be funny and then remembered its manners. There was a brace in the rail under the stage where kids liked to sit with their legs hanging and pretend the boy next to them was not beautiful; there was a battery bolted to the celebrated history of dance posters; there was pine cleaner in the places where no child’s shoe would ever wipe it away.

It was not a second hunt. That would give too much credit to the thrill of it. It was a cleaning. She went with Lev and Havel and sometimes alone to places where people had placed their soft things and tucked a steel idea under them. They found one under a pew where the wood had a notch from boys’ pocketknives and the stain wore down like a river; they found one at the veterinary office chain clipped to the bottom of a supply shelf that only a hand fishing for gauze would ever touch; they found a small one hidden in the idea a bench had of its own leg at the bus stop where two women kissed and luck held for once. Each time she felt the small satisfaction that comes with disarming something clever and mean, but it never took the taste of metal out of her mouth, and she went home after the fourth and washed her hands with a ferocity that made Olia come stand in the doorway and say, in a voice that could carry a child and a fight, enough now, come sit.

Mara purchased packets of seed like talismans and made herself busy with what could be done now, which was gather names and plant small stars and show up wherever showing up would build a wall you might later lean against. She came to the Park Strip with a box of trowels that had belonged to a nursery she had worked in in college and had carried now like a first-aid kit through three apartments and two griefs, and she handed them out to whoever showed their bare hands. People kneeled and pressed seed into ground in rows that were not straight and no one minded, and the park, which had carried candles and apologies and fear, began to carry preparation of a gentler kind. Lady watched the blades of their hands and the slope of their spines and realized again the absurdity of evil thinking it can make a world out of a single man’s desires when you can stand on a public lawn and watch eighty people decide dirt is how we start over.

In the evenings she sat with Lev on his tailgate while he spun out stories that admitted he had been afraid when his daughter told him who she loved not because of her love but because of the world, and that he had learned to be brave by practicing small embarrassments like going to the parade with a sign that said Dad and then not dying of it. He taught her the names of clouds when they are above water and behave worse, and she gave him names of invasive weeds because she is a woman who believes naming things is the first way you make a dent in them. They did not talk about Brendan much unless the conversation asked them to, and when it did they kept their words as plain as unsalted bread.

The bunker’s hum did not come back in the way that would cause someone to put a finger to their teeth and say oh. It came back one afternoon as a tremulous suggestion that made her fill a kettle and spill water onto her stove because she had let the thought pull her away from the motion of pouring. Whoever had cut into rock and fed it machines had not been content with absence. Havel sent men with degrees and careful shoes and they came out with sentences about residual resonance and the way concrete holds what is asked of it for longer than is fair, and Lady smiled with accuracy that made the men like her even if they did not notice the laugh at their expense sit under it. Later, she went herself and stood on the shelf where the borage had done its short brave season, and she put her hand on the bruise of the seam and counted heartbeats and found only her own.

If there is a man behind a man, and there usually is when a thing turns from terror into a project, you have to learn his habits the way you learn when to pick raspberries without being stung. She went to the thrift store where old denim went to be forgiven and asked a teenager with green bangs to tell her about a jacket with a compass sewn on, and the girl reminded her of someone who had found a map and decided it did not apply. The jacket had been on a man who smelled like yellow nicotine and had tipped with his forefinger and thumb because he did not like letting go of anything with the whole hand; he had said the compass would help him find true when the world insisted on making false sound pretty; he had had the letters C L E A N tattooed across his left knuckles, the work faded but careful. The girl had fancied herself a novelist and had taken a picture of his hands to describe them later and had saved the picture behind six layers of folders labeled cat and homework and definitely_not_porn, and she showed Lady, who took the image with her phone and a promise to bring the girl snap peas that would make her consider learning the taste of green with gratitude.

On a dry day with a wind that wanted to help, Havel took the picture to a man he knew whose job it was to remember men who had been in and out of jail long enough to be cousin to both doors. A name fell out like a nail from a mouth. Ephraim Marsh, called Marsh by men who pretended they didn’t leave home with Bible words in their pockets; a welder by early training and later choice; a man who had gotten religion twice and liked the second better; a man who had taught a few boys to make things in a fire and to believe that making and punishing are twin crafts. He had a wife once who put her hand on a stove and then claimed she had never leaned on anything hot; he had a trailer in a park that had organized itself against trailers and lost.

When they went to the trailer park, the wind was doing the polite thing of not pulling the siding off houses despite having the power. Marsh’s trailer had a maroon stripe across it that had faded to a kind of embarrassed pink; there were deer antlers wired to the porch light and a compass rose cut from aluminum fixed to the door with self-tapping screws. He was not home because he had understood how to read a world that had decided it needed him, but the smell was right and the ashtray had cigarettes in it crushed in a way that matched the way the cigarette in the shed had been crushed. In the sink lay a rag that had been used for pine and then oil, and in the little room with the table and the two chairs a notebook with holes punched in the wrong places held sketches of braces and notes about torque and a list of places where it would be funny if a man put a small lever and then walked away. Lady took pictures and tried not to mutate the sorrow into fury because fury eats the part of you that can recognize a child when he is standing there dressed in a man’s one good shirt.

She slept badly two nights in a row and then, as always, slept like a boulder. In the dream that found her in that third sleep, she stood at the shore again and the old door in rock had become a hive entrance and inside the hum was bees full of work and nobody asked anything of them except the thing they wanted to do. When she woke, her pillow smelled like rosemary because she had tucked a sprig there thinking it would chase whatever it is that chases you at three in the morning out the window. She made coffee, took the jar with Mara’s seeds, and went to the edge of the garden where the wind and the cold have an agreement to test what gets planted there. She sowed, and for once did not think metaphor all the way through. She wanted flowers because the world needed something to go mad over that did not bite you back.

Marsh did not announce himself in the way Brendan had. He did not send invitations to overlooks. He went quiet and then went cunning, and the blog with its borrowed tone began to post observed details that only a man who had been teacher and altar boy to bad ideas would enjoy sharing. There was a passage about schools wanting to smear children in safety until they could no longer recognize hazard, and a photograph of a locker room bench with the legs rebolted but at an angle clever in the wrong way. There was a line about how water had cleansed the world once and would again if we would only give it the permission a man could give, and a photograph of a drainage ditch with trampled grass. They were breadcrumbs that believed themselves stones, and Lady, who had followed rabbits through willows as a girl and had learned that the path the animal takes is not the path that gets you back out without cutting your shins open, took one look and did not go where he had set the table.

They found Marsh by subtraction, which feels less romantic and more satisfying than it gets credit for. Havel’s men knocked on doors and someone’s aunt who had been tired for twenty-one years said she had seen him go into a storage unit with a roll-up door near the tanning salon and not come out. Lev called twice with the pointed casualness of a man pretending to call about the weather and a boat, and on the second call his voice had that hand-to-the-rib attention that always made Lady sit down. There was a smell on the river that did not belong to river, and the gulls were quiet, and a truck had parked on the shoulder a mile past where anyone with sense would park because the shoulder there thinks it is a slide. Lady put her boots on because all stories were going to end in mud anyway and because you cannot grow anything without accepting that sometimes you need to step in what rots.

They came to the unit together, a ridiculous little procession with badges and rope and a woman with a trowel in her pack because you carry the tool your hands know even into rooms where it is ridiculous. The lock was new enough to be proud of itself. The man who ran the place had a ring jangling at his belt that let him believe he was friend to metal, and when he lifted the door and the unkind light came in cold and sideways it found a workbench that had not learned any manners since they’d last seen one. Marsh was there at the far end, not surprised, cigarette burned down to a thought, hands stained in a way that hides even in soap. He had the braces on the wall arranged like a choir, small to large, and between them the compass roses cut from whatever had been handy. He had a single jar on the bench with borage seeds in it that he had stolen from someone’s stall because people like him cannot help but take the symbol, and when he saw Lady look he smiled with a paternal pain and asked if she thought planting would save anyone.

Havel did not let him finish speaking, and Lady loved him again for the economy. There was motion, the kind that looks terrible if you stop it with a camera and looks like rescue if you let it play, and then there were wrists cuffed and a man making the sounds men make when they are realizing their version of god has invented limits. Marsh’s left hand showed what the teenager had said and Lady found herself staring at the letters as if they were a talisman with the power to undo their bearer. C L E A N, and the tattoos had been touched up once and then not again because poverty had made everything temporary but faith. He looked at her with the particular contempt men save for women who do things without asking them first, and she tilted her head in the same not-quite-nod she had given Brendan. If there was pity in her, it belonged to the child who had been told that violence was a sermon and had believed because the grownups in the room had made it easier than learning a different hymn.

Afterward there were the things people bring to kitchens when they don’t know what else to bring, and Lady’s table held deviled eggs and potato salads and cookies wrapped in wax paper with an elastic band like a promise. Olia put her foot down about men being allowed to open the refrigerator without being told where the milk lived, and Lev sat at the stoop and told a passerby that he had been an idiot for thirty years and had decided to take a shorter route for the next thirty. Rhea arrived late with tired eyes and a grin that said she had skipped a meeting, and she brought her own fork because she had learned the hard way where forks go in break rooms. Mara came with dirt under her nails and a stack of little paper cups that said courage, and when she hugged Lady, Lady let herself be held as if she were also a person who deserved it.

It was not over, because things like this do not end; they get rearranged until you can live with them without bleeding every time you turn and brush against the shelf. There would be court, and there would be a jury that became a character in other people’s dinner conversation, and there would be names in the paper and reporters who smelled like a dangerous mixture of good intentions and rent. There would be a vigil later not for the dead this time but for the living who had had devices removed from under their elbows, and someone would sing off-key and it would be the best version of that song that had ever been sung. There would be the unglamorous work of unscrewing brackets from the undersides of tables and teaching janitors to look where they never wanted to look, and there would be a day where a boy sat on a bench and did not get hurt. And there would be a morning when the borage bloomed in the worst part of the garden and the bees forgot diplomacy and flung themselves at the blue, and Lady would stand and let the sound of their work get into her bones and remake the hum that had lived there for a week into a different song entirely.

On the longest day of the year, when the sun wheeled and refused to sit and the gulls forgot to sleep, Lady Palov’s cabbages lay like green helmets in their bed. She moved through the rows in boots still damp from fog, her braid tucked into a cap with a tattered patch of a moose stitched on. Between the stalks of kale and the delicate frills of dill, her hands found the soil she had mixed and turned and sung to all spring. You could coax anything out of the ground, given enough time and care and a willingness to break up stubborn clods.

She ran the tip of a finger along a carrot frond and lifted it to her nose. Soil, iron, that cold clean smell that belonged to high latitudes. The June sun had rubbed warmth onto everything except the wind. The wind still bit.

From the road behind her fence came the hush of tires, a pickup rolling slow, and then the rattle changed as it hit the washboard. She did not look up immediately. There were always trucks. People always going somewhere, arriving with news or supplies or nothing at all. She had learned not to break her rhythm for any engine.

When she did look, it was because a shadow cut over the kale. Raven. Another, then three. The ravens had found something on the gravel rise. She straightened, brushed soil onto her jeans, and squinted through the thin birch. The pickup had stopped by Old Rookery Lane. Two men in neon vests were leaning against it and looking at their phones. The ravens were hopping nowhere near them—just above the ditch, where water seeped all year and cattails held their green flags up like dry laughter. A fox was there too, in red, low as a rumor.

“Hey,” Lady said aloud, small word chambered against the morning. “Not in my ditch. Go find something else.”
