The ravens ignored her, as ravens will. The fox flicked an ear and then arrowed away. She stood a minute longer, listening for the hint, the wrong note in the day. Her hands were empty; she had left her trowel stuck like a silver leaf in the lettuce bed. The breeze turned and put a voice in her ear.

“Palov!”

Olia, her neighbor, leaned over the fence with arms brown and strong beneath her flannel. Olia had two kids, a degree in library science nobody had wanted to hire this far north, and a permanent half-laugh in her voice.

“You seeing the news?” she called. “Check your phone.”

Lady wiped her fingers on her thighs and patted her pockets. No phone. It was in the mudroom, she thought, next to the jar of slug beer traps. She shook her head.

“What now?” she asked.

“Some blog,” Olia said. “Man says he—says he hurt somebody. Again. In the city. People are already screaming in the comments about trolls and hoaxes but, I swear, some of the details. It’s ugly.”

Lady felt the wrong note deepen. The ravens said nothing now. They lifted into the pale brightness with long wings and went toward town. The men by the truck still looked down and scrolled.

“I’ll be right back,” Lady said, and went to the mudroom, to the phone, to that tenuous tether between the garden and the things that had teeth and data and no patience.

The blog had a name that was both pompous and childish. True North. Always a compass rose logo, its points sharpened until they were more knives than symbols. The lead post had a date and a line break and then:

Late nights leave the mind clear. They try to hide in hospitals, but they still go home, and you can find anyone who thinks he’s safe when the streetlights die. You feel it when they lie. Their voices shake. They say things in the little rooms, words that tear holes in you, like they know better. I don’t forget. I am not a myth. My hands remember every bone.

Below, a prairie of comments, the internet doing what it does—hallelujah, horror, laughter, attempts at locating this voice or burying it. Many small anonymous faces knocking against the words without ever touching the man behind them. People had screens between them and felt brave.

Olia’s text came through.

You see? Anchorage PD is quoted in ADN. Doc found in the alley behind Clementine’s. Crushed. That’s the word they used. Crushed. No way to do that except with a car, they say, but there was no impact, no marks, just… yeah.

Lady read the word twice and then put the screen down. She did not like seeing it next to her lettuce. She did not like the thought of an alley behind a café she had eaten at, and a man who helped people lying on concrete that had been warmed all day by June light, and then someone… No. She thought of bones and of the sound soil makes when you press in a fist and then let go.

She washed her hands and watched the water run brown, then clear. She put the phone face down on the counter and went back out. The wind had picked up and the cabbage leaves sighed as if gossiping among themselves.

Olia was still there, chewing on a swizzle stick, which she had the habit of doing since she quit cigarettes. “You knew him?” she asked, softer now.

Lady shook her head. “I know a lot of doctors,” she said. “He may have been one.” She left it there.

People came through her garden and her kitchen with headaches and sprains and stories and broken hearts, and she brewed teas and blistered peppers and sent them away with instructions for sleep. She did not doctor anyone. She would not pretend that. But she had a way with care.

She pinched a slug off a kale leaf and tossed it to the gravel. An eagle wheeled down by the river, slow as doubt. And she said, because she heard it assembling in her like a plant deciding to send up a stalk, “I’m going to the city.”

“To do what?” Olia asked. The swizzle stick made a small crack.

“To see,” Lady said. “Just to see how it sits. There’s something wrong out of frame. If nobody hears it, it will grow teeth.”

Olia nodded once. They were not dramatic people. The small town pretended there was no drama anywhere in it, not really. But they watched, and when watching was not enough, they moved their boots.

She packed like a woman going for groceries; a thermos of coffee, a bag of jerky, a book with a cracked spine. She tucked her trowel into the glove box and laughed at herself and took it out again. She left a note on the table for anyone who might come: gone for a day, maybe two, water the cucumbers if you’re here, don’t let the rooster into the greenhouse even if he pleads.

The road into Anchorage was glass and then gravel and then glass again. The birch slivers widened, the spruce got tired, there were billboards for lawyers with outsized heads, and then there were more people than Lady was used to seeing on a weekday morning. She kept her radio off because she didn’t want a voice bouncing against the inside of her skull. She kept seeing the word crushed. She imagined a hand that could do it. Not metaphor, not exaggeration—bone and sinew smashed by other bone and sinew. A hand capable of making a human ribcage as flat as an onion leaf. It didn’t fit. It fit too well.

At the edge of the city, she saw two women kissing by the bus stop. She thought of the blog and its voice thick with grudge and bitter grammar, and something inside her reached for a tool. It found none. It found only a memory: her cousin Nastya, almost ten years ago, introduced as a roommate. Later, with a tremble, as more. Later, in tears, calling from a porch on a dark night when a man driving by had thrown a bottle and a word like a stone. “I hate who you are,” the blog would say, without saying it so plainly. “I hate your cells, your breath.” It would talk about purity and truth like a person reaching for a clean handkerchief while his shoes dripped blood.

Parking on Third Avenue, she drank lukewarm coffee and watched two gulls fighting over a french fry old as Saturday. The city had its own beats; people with backpacks shaped like mountains moving faster than anyone in her town ever moved. On the windows of the café there were papers taped up, and she squinted. Counselors. Hotlines. Vigil tonight on the Park Strip for Dr. Alex Clement. Bring candles. Be kind.

She went around to the alley and found it exactly as alleys are: a bad idea in the dark and a corridor in the day. There was a stain that could have been anything. There was chalk at the end of it, the kind used by little children. Someone had written in unsteady blocks: be gentle with each other.

Two officers stood halfway down the alley talking into their radios and measuring the world with glances. Lady kept her distance; she had no authority here. She touched the wall and felt heat. She crouched and felt the concrete and it did not talk. You had to know where to touch and which questions to ask and how to listen when the answer wanted to stay stone.

But smell. She could smell. Detergent. Pine. Someone had scrubbed. The scrub had not been enough, but it was trying.

“Miss?” one officer said, tired more than suspicious.

“I’m just looking,” she said. “I’m not stepping on anything. I have a garden. I come into town sometimes.” She heard her own voice sounding like nothing at all.

“We do not need lookers,” he said, and then softened. “Lady Palov?” He had a sister who bought lavender from her every winter, who sent a Christmas card with a picture of a dog wearing a sweater. He recognized her. “You shouldn’t be here.”

She looked at his face. He was not happy with any of this. He had slept badly for several years running.

“I saw the blog,” she said.

The other officer rolled his eyes. “Everyone has seen the blog. You’d think the devil himself would want less attention.”

Lady shook her head. “The devil wants attention. He’s a child.”

The first officer almost smiled. He looked over her shoulder like he had to remember his job at intervals, like it was a thing that could slip out of his hands if he did not grip it on purpose. “Go home, Lady,” he said finally. “Let us get a handle on this. There’s too much gossip. We got a lot of nothing. Weight we can’t lift. He—whoever he is—he wants to be loud. That makes him sloppy. We’ll get him.”

It was a good line. It would be said at a press conference later, and people would feel a little better for five minutes.

But Lady, who had replanted whole beds after early frosts, who had learned what you could salvage and what you couldn’t, heard the spaces between the words. Loud did not always mean sloppy. Sometimes a person had learned to be both loud and meticulous. It happened. She thought of carving knives hung in neat black rolls.

She went to the vigil with her hands empty because flowers felt wrong, too easy. There were candles with trembling flames, there was a man singing a song he had not memorized all the way through, there were people in fleece vests and grief. Lady found a corner of the green where the snow had gone last, where it always stayed a little colder. She stood and heard a woman speak about Dr. Clement. He had stitched her boy’s eyebrow, he had made the boy laugh while he did it. He had said something about scars being maps you earn and how some maps you would prefer not to have to travel.

Later, after the song, after the slow dispersal of people into streets where the sky still was pale, after she had written the word courage in small letters on a paper cup and set it down by others, she sat on a bench and opened the blog again. Another post since morning. The author had no schedule, as if he wrote when the pressure rose, when heat demanded a vent.

I won’t be stopped by the ones who say their job is to fix. Fixers break what they don’t understand. You don’t understand me. You never did. You told me I was wrong, wrong, wrong in my bones. So I show you bones. Simple. Hands are tools. Mine are clean.

She thought of the word clean. It was doing heavy lifting there. She saw, as in a slide show behind her eyelids, a basement floor painted red long ago, glossy. She saw gloves turned inside out and snapped like flags and a sink someone had scrubbed too hard and a drain that clung to secrets. She saw ice. She saw a shoreline not far from town where the tide went out for miles and back again like a remorseless animal.

She went to a motel with a neon salmon and a heater that clicked like an impatient teacher. She slept badly and woke from a dream in which she was laying a drip line and found instead she was laying down words into a comment field. Her finger hovered. It felt like letting a line into a river with no idea what fish lived there.

She wrote: Your compass is wrong. North is not the thing you love. It’s the thing that gets you lost. I plant things. I watch what grows. I know clean when I see it. Your clean is no such thing.

It went into the stream with the rest of it. Most comments sank almost at once, or bobbed for a second and were pushed by the current into some eddy that had no witnesses. She did not expect an answer. People who wanted to be looked at did not want to be seen.

An hour later, as the heater clicked and the salmon in neon flickered and someone in the next room coughed in a way that made her want to brew mint, there was a notification.

He wrote: Do you plant by the coast. There are plants that belong to salt and wind, and plants that belong to the shadow line where the tide stops. I prefer the places the tide never quite reaches. People forget those places. They get soft with distance.

No name. No address. Words that gave away nothing they didn’t mean to. But—tidelines. Her shoulders went tight, then loosened. He was here. He was here like weather is here. He was thinking like a shoreline, and that narrowed a map.

She wrote back: I’ve planted everywhere. My boots remember every mile. Don’t worry too much about fingerprints. Soil has a way of keeping its own log.

There was no reply for hours, and when she closed her eyes she heard gulls standing on the right side of a roof and not the left, heard snow topple from the earth’s shoulders into the right bay and not the left. She slept and woke and drove with coffee that was ash by noon. She went to the water and sat with her feet in her boots on a rock that had been warmed in slow increments by a sun that was quicker than it should be.

She was not a detective, she told herself. She did not solve crimes. She made soups and stitched split hose and coaxed basil where basil ought to be shy. But then her phone lit like a fish in dark water. Another comment. From him. Not to her alone; to the world, in the next post, but it felt personal enough to make her breath change.

It read:

They will think they know me, and they will be wrong. They will say monster like it’s a coat they can drape over anyone who scares them. Fine. I like to wear their words. Is a monster someone who does what must be done. Is it someone who refuses to be remade. They tried to make me soft like the ones who kiss in the alleys, like the ones who cry when told the truth. Don’t call that hate. Call it gravity. If you stand wrong, it pulls you down. I am the correction.

She shut off the screen with a hard, angry thumb. There was a weed poking up in the cracks of the rock, a thin, red heartbeat of a stem, and she pulled it out with a twist and held it until the small root went limp in her fingers.

He wasn’t hiding. He was daring. He had a rhythm. He would talk, and then he would do. Words like footsteps. She watched the tide bring a line of wrack, fine foam, a few feathers, a dead crab that had been thoroughly considered by gulls. What places did the tide never quite reach. Places of rock shelves where it skimmed off, places the maps marked with a gray smear and a string of soundings: 30, 30, 30.

She thought of a friend of her father’s who had worked on the radars back when they were still testing things and the navy came up with cold hands and loud pockets. She remembered a story about an old submarine base beyond the point. Not the big place in the history books, the one tourists wanted pictures of. Another one, off-road, old concrete in the moss, tunnel mouths like cave drawings of mouths. Most people had no reason to know it. You had to be a person who listened when elders spoke, if they ever did. Her father laughed; he had been better at listening than speaking. He had told her: there are places like jars, they collect the wrong kind of rain.

She went back to the motel and tore the advertisement for whale-watching out of a stand and started a map on the back of it with a pencil that had been used to crossword until it was down to a nub. The lines were not confident at first; then they learned muscle memory. Road, turnoff, gravel, mud. Her finger found the spot like a diviner’s stick. Maybe. Maybe not. Somewhere along that coast, the tide would do what he liked. There would be caves or there would be doors cut into rock. Or—these days—there would be something even quieter: a boathouse, a research station, pretending to be empty.

Her phone buzzed. Not him. Rhea—doctor in Homer, hair usually exploding out of a bun, eyes always trying to look both stern and kind at the same time and never succeeding because she was too kind. Rhea’s voice on the line: rough. “You in town too?” she asked. Lady could hear wind behind her, a street, someone laughing the way people laugh when they have nothing to do with someone else’s grief and they are embarrassed to be happy.

“I’m here,” Lady said. “I saw the alley.”

“I shouldn’t say anything,” Rhea said, which was how most doctors began sentences they very much wanted to finish. “But there is something wrong. They’re calling him the Crusher on the forums. Jesus. They say he’s writing all these posts. The boys in blue think it’s bluster. I don’t think so. He knows things you don’t know unless you’ve sat in rooms like I sit in. He knows the vocabulary, he just has it twisted so that it stabs.”

“I know,” Lady said.

“No, listen.” Rhea’s breathing slowed a notch; she was bringing herself into her exam-room voice, the one she used for people who had been told the first diagnosis and needed the second one to have hope. “I don’t think he’s just angry. I think he’s planned. And I think his hands are not—normal. They said crushed. I set fractures. I’ve felt bone. You can’t do that with just hands, Lady. Not even with adrenaline and rage. You need leverage. You need a tool. Or you need something else.”

Lady thought of the word else like a door with no handle. “You mean metal.”

“Or bone,” Rhea said. “Built differently. He might be strong. Or he might be someone who learned where to press. There are ways to make a body fold that look like force when what they really are is knowledge. I hate the thought of him knowing us that well. The way our doors give.”

Lady sat on the edge of the motel bed and looked at a stain on the carpet that was shaped like a fish with too many fins. “Have you eaten,” she asked, because it was her trick for when conversations toppled into pits.

Rhea laughed. “A granola bar six hours ago. I know. I know. You don’t have to bring me soup from thirty miles away. Stay safe. You hear me?”

Lady said she heard. After she ended the call, she wiped her eyes with the heel of her hand. She was not crying for the dead. Not now. She was crying for the angle of the blog’s words, for the way they slid like sleet under her coat. He was not a child in the usual way. He had teeth, yes, but also he had craft. It scared her more than teeth.

The next morning, she woke early and went to a hardware store because that’s where hope goes to browse in the dark. She bought a heavy flashlight, a new coil of rope, a bag of salt meant for thaw. The man behind the counter asked her if she had ice in June, and she smiled without meaning to and said always. She went to the dock afterward and watched boats cough into life. A man was adjusting a red cap and cursing because a knot had seized. She asked if he could spare ten minutes for a hundred dollars and he laughed and said he’d spare twenty for fifty if she wasn’t asking him to smuggle diamonds.

“Just a ferry to the point,” she said. “I’ll walk back.”

He looked at her boots and at the bag she held and at the line of her shoulders. “People don’t walk back from there for fun,” he said, but he gestured her aboard.

The water was flat and green-blue and deceptive; it looked gentle and would turn on you like a mood. He cut around the point a little farther than a ferry would, and he pointed with his chin at the old bunkers and the collapsing dock invisible under the tide. The gulls knew every nail. “Navy built those,” he said, like a man telling a child there had once been dragons, whether or not he believed in dragons now.

She looked beyond the obvious, past the graffiti and the caved-in roofline. The rock itself had a seam that was too straight to be only rock. Trees spilled over it like hair over a brow. There were four steps of old concrete rungs half-swallowed by seaweed. When he dropped her on what passed for a beach there—a narrow ridge where the tide flung logs like it was bored with them—he looked ill at ease.

“You want me to wait,” he said, no question mark.

“Not for long,” she said.

She went up, feeling like a person approaching a sleeping bear. She didn’t hunch; she knew enough not to pant like prey. She kept steady. She found the seam. It was a door, of course it was. It had been painted the color of conversation and then they had let weather eat the paint. Up close, you could see fingerprints in the grime where someone had been careful, preserving and not preserving at once.

It was locked. Hard. Not the kind of lock a bolt cutter eats for breakfast; one of those designed to look industrial and humble and turn a simple barrier into a statement. She pressed her cheek to the cold and smelled salt and rust and distant oil. The tide hissed and hissed like a cranky kettle. She didn’t call out. You don’t wake anything if you don’t have to.

On the rock by the door was a smear in the lichen, something like grease, something grayer, slicker. She touched it with the tip of the flashlight and then didn’t. She got the bag of salt out and held it and felt ridiculous because that wasn’t the right tool for any version of this problem. But she had what she had.

She crouched and looked at the ground just like she'd look at a bed she was planning to plant. Scuffed. Yes. Not heavily. A single person, often. He had a path even if he didn’t admit it to himself. Human feet made patterns. The path drifted toward a little shelf where the rock slicked with algae. She saw something that snagged even before she knew it had. A print. Bare. Larger than average. The toes splayed wider than they should, like a hand. It was not a human footprint, if human is what you meant by normal. Or it was a human footprint that had spent a long time gripping things it shouldn’t, toes trained like fingers. She took a picture without the flash. She took another.

Shadows moved at the corner of her eye. A seal surfaced and looked at her with the bland curiosity of a creature who has seen too many shipwrecks to care.

Her phone buzzed. Her hand snatched at it and then she was angry at herself for being jumpy. Screen. A new response to a thread. The blog:

They troll the docks like gulls. They think I’m there because I talk about tide lines. They don’t know what a tide line is. It’s something that draws itself. People who draw themselves are harder to unmake. Are you listening, gardener. You know root systems. I walked in your yard once. You weren’t home.

Her breath came in wrong.

She read it again.

She tasted metal.

She dropped the phone into the pocket because dropping it into the sea would fix nothing, and turned, slow, like a person who had heard a twig break in the wrong forest. She looked for cameras tucked into driftwood. She looked for a figure on the ridge. She saw the boat waiting beyond the point, the man in the red cap smoking and pretending to be bored. She smelled the grease again, closer now, like the memory of machines.

The door had no handle on this side, but it had a small lip where it met the jamb. She took the rope and the salt and felt like a magician fumbling their one trick. She did not need to get in today. She needed to know that this was a place, and it was. The tide came in a little, a little more.

When she got back to the boat, the man looked at her face and said nothing. He pushed off with easy efficiency, as if he could pretend they had gone out and sat in the quiet just to look for whales. Halfway back to the harbor, he said, not looking at her, “If you got a bad feeling, it’s because there is something bad there. I don’t like being around things that aren’t what they are.” It was a complicated sentence, and he spoke it slowly, like he had been moving it around in his mouth for years.

“Thank you for taking me,” Lady said. She gave him more money than he had asked for. He would try to give some back, and she would let him keep it. It would let him buy gloves that wouldn’t fail in November.

Back on land, she sat in her truck, and said the names of weeds she knew when she needed calm. Knotweed. Creeping jenny. Horsetail. Lamb’s quarters. She had always loved lamb’s quarters because it sounded like a nursery and was as persistent as anything alive. She thought of the footprint. She thought of toes that knew how to spread like a fan, of nails that had thickened, of the way someone had trained themselves to be what they had wanted nobody to name. Is monster a coat. Could you take it off, could you dry it in a soft wind. Not relevant, she told herself. The question did not change the bones. Bones were done, set.

She drove back to town and then toward home, and the ravens were in her ditch again when she got there, and she laughed a little because laughter was a tool too. On the porch was a jar of her own jam, unopened, and a note from Olia that said: You went. Be careful. The rooster tried to come in and Nik put him right back out again, don’t worry. We watered the cucumbers even though they don’t deserve it. 

Inside, her house smelled like pine cleaner and dill. She considered packing for a longer drive; she considered talking to anyone at all. She made tea, instead, and sat at the table with the True North blog open like a mouth. She scrolled until her thumb cramped and found an old post from months ago. It had a line that transformed under her eyes now that she had stood by that door and touched grease.

You can hear the hum in the stone if you put your ear to it. They built the hum into it. It never leaves. Even when nobody is home, the noise leaks. You have to get used to it. It makes some people wild. I like it. It’s like being held by something big that doesn’t care.

That was not a hospital. That was machinery embedded in land. That was a cave with electrical arteries. That was a menacing lack of care made into a comfort. That matched the hum she had felt in her teeth near the door. She put her head down on her arms for a minute and let an old ache rise up—the ache of what you know and can’t show anyone yet. Evidence, they would say. Show me. She’d show them a footprint and a smear and they would shrug.

No. She would show them his replies.

She wrote again, not in the comments this time, but in a private message system that the blog had bolted on like an afterthought. People like him loved control; they loved being able to choose who they answered.

She wrote: If you know plants then you know that some can poison the ground for everything else for years. Some can fix nitrogen. Which do you want to be, in the end. You think you’re cleaning. You’re salting the field.

There was no answer for a while. The rooster crowed at nothing, and she yelled at him to keep it down. An hour later, the message pinged.

He wrote: You think in dirt. You think slow. That’s fine. I’m faster. You already saw where I go. I saw your yard. I was going to take your trowel and leave it by your front step like a bad joke, but I thought better of it. Your trowel is an honest thing.

His honesty was not.

Her hands went around the mug until the hot found bone.

She wrote: I saw your footprint.

He wrote: Good. I like when people look. He included a picture: a close-up of bark, a small lichen the shape of a handprint in green. “The world is made of maps.”

He was showing off. He was careless, because he had been careful so long that he wanted to dare himself. That was the crack. Pride is a frost and a flame. It swells wood and opens doors that never should open.

She made a list by the sink, ink bleeding a little into cheap paper:

- Door at point, locked; hum behind it. 
- Footprint: toes spread. Not human-normal. 
- He knows me. He was here. He didn’t take anything. 
- He likes the idea of clean; equates violence with purity. Hates softness and kindness; thinks they make him dirty.
- He says tide line not reached by tide. He wants margins.
- Rhea says hands or tools or both. Not just strength.
- Captain with red cap. Call him again.

She added at the top: The name Brendan, because that was what the news had begun to call him that afternoon, a detail they believed they had threaded from the blog into a tip into a history of a boy who had changed his name at nineteen and his occupation at thirty-three and his body somehow along the way. Brendan. She had known a Brendan in school, a boy who could deadlift a moose if it asked nicely and who had cried once when the theater teacher gave him a real role. Names were never the point.

A car slowed at her mailbox. She went to the window and peered through her stalk of african violets. The car was black and shiny and had the sort of tight mouth police departments prefer to drive. One of the officers from the alley got out and removed his sunglasses carefully like they were a small animal and he didn’t want to scare it away.

“You left town without telling us,” he said when she came to the porch. He sounded injured more than accusing.

“I’m not on your team,” she said, no apology in it.

“You’re on my Christmas card list,” he said. “My sister will kill me if something happens to you and I could have stopped it.” He looked at the trees as if expecting them to hum. “We’ve had more posts. We’ve got a name. We think he lives—or lived—in a place that burned down outside the city. In the woods. He got into fights. He hates—” He tripped over the list of people the man hated and settled on “difference.” It was not quite enough and too small and a hundred miles safer than the truth.

“He walks without shoes sometimes,” Lady said. “He goes to the coast. There’s an old place he uses.”

The officer blinked at her and then breathed in like he had swallowed ice. “You went out there.” Not a question.

She nodded. “You should too. Carefully. Bring a person who can listen. The door is not a metaphor. It has a lock that means business.”

His mouth tightened. “Why do it, Lady. Why call himself this and that and write things like he’s selling tickets to his own circus. Most of them hide. He preens.”

“Some people need to hear themselves,” she said. “They don’t believe they’re real until their voice bounces back from a wall.” She thought of concrete under moss. She thought of sound. She looked back into her house unconsciously, as if she would be able to see which chair he had wanted to leave the trowel on. She thought of his feet on her floor, or worse, on the lawn by the cold frames. She thought of him moving like an animal that had been taught a terrible trick and then taught to wear clothes over it.

“I’m going back,” she said, because the world had narrowed into a path and she had learned over years of frost and slug and late blight when to step and when to shelter, and this was a stepping time. “I have to. I can smell when a storm is almost here. Standing still is not the right response.”

He put his sunglasses back on softly and said that he had not heard anything, nor had he asked, and then he thanked her for the small jar of pickled radishes she hadn’t yet offered him and left with them tucked under one arm like a gift he wanted to pretend was his idea too.

That night, the sky never truly darkened. The clouds did something like a shrug and then like a turn. The garden breathed. In the house, Lady packed again. It was not theatrical. She put rope and salt and flashlight in a backpack. She added something she hadn’t before: a coil of galvanized wire, thick enough to bite back. She put her old fishing knife in her boot and then took it out and put it in the pack where it wouldn’t cut her calf on a run. She left another note: don’t let him in.

The blog had gone quiet for a few hours, which felt like a held breath. She went outside and lay on the cool grass between the peppers and the potatoes and thought of the old submarines gliding under the skin of the world. Of doors in rock. Of hands like fans. Of people who kissed by bus stops and of Dr. Clement making a boy laugh while stitching him and saying something about maps. Of Rhea eating granola bars six hours apart and trying to be kind faster than cruelty could arrive.

She thought, too, of the hum a place can have and the way it can get into your bones and make them ring until you think the ringing is you. Say a prayer, she told herself, though she didn’t do that. Or make a promise. Better. She made one: I will stop you. The words felt foolish and grand and necessary. On her tongue, they tasted like spruce tips and iron.

At the edge of sleep, she heard a movement in the yard and reached for nothing at all, which was what she had. A moose considered the kale and decided this wasn’t the hour for it. The rooster murmured a complaint. The thermometer dropped one degree. The ravens whispered to each other in a language that was mostly laughter and death. The night was thin and full of sound. She slept anyway.

Morning brought wind from the west and a text from the man with the red hat. Someone had been in his yard during the night, he said. No harm done, but footprints in the patch of bare dirt by his shed. Toes spread. He could laugh about a lot of things. He did not laugh about that.

She wrote back: Lock your doors. He wrote: Not a man who locks them usually, but I will.

And she, Lady Palov, gardener, not detective, who had learned patience from carrots and speed from first frosts, put on her boots and checked the knots at the corners of her resolve. Sometimes you plant. Sometimes you pull. Sometimes you lay down salt and say not here, not this. She stood in her doorway, listened one last time to a house that held her, and went out into the near-daylight toward a place where something alive and cruel thought it had found a perfect tide line that would never wash it away.

The first thing she did was check the tide tables, not online where a glitch could lie to you, but on the dog-eared card tacked up in the general store between scissors for sale and a picture of someone’s labrador that had gone missing and then been found. The calendar had been printed ten years ago but the pencil marks added every season kept it honest, and when she ran her finger along the numbers for that week the knowledge slotted into place with a quiet satisfaction that had nothing to do with joy. Low water would loosen its hold on the rocks in the midafternoon, and if she timed it right she would have two hours of standing room where there was usually a green hand pressing you toward the sea. The man with the red cap had texted with a picture of the footprint by his shed, and she had stared way too long at the splayed toes until her stomach reminded her she had coffee and nothing else inside it. She ate bread over the sink, the crumbs making their polite arcs onto the plate like small votes for returning to bed, and then she laced her boots and put her face into the wind.

She told no one the exact hour she meant to leave because she had learned, hard, that telling too many people your plan was one decent way to make sure you walked into a plan someone else had made. Instead she went to Olia’s fence and talked about cucumbers until the way Olia’s mouth turned told her the conversation had reached the point where friends who knew better didn’t ask what you meant to do because it was already too late. The officer from Anchorage, who had sat at her kitchen table yesterday like a man trying to decide whether to confess or to nap, had a name now—Havel—and when she texted him she kept the words as simple as seeds. Shore. Old base. Low tide. He replied with a dot, then another, then finally a sentence: Don’t go in. We’re assembling a team. The sentence wore a neat collar it didn’t deserve, and she pocketed the phone with the knowledge that teams took time and time was a thing that flowed whether you asked it to or not.

At the dock, the man with the red cap had his hands sunk wrist-deep in a coil of line like he was reminding the rope who had authority. His cap had lost some of its red to the sun and his beard had won a few more gray bristles since yesterday, and when she climbed aboard without waiting to be invited he only shook his head with the generous annoyance of someone who knew fighting certain kinds of stubborn was like fighting weather. He pushed off and held the tiller with his hand the same way she held a trowel, like he knew how much the tool would help and how much it would betray.

“You said footprints in your yard,” she said while the boat skipped over the smaller moods of the water.

“Bare,” he said, and spat over the side softly like a man paying a toll. “Soft spot by the cordwood. I ain’t fancy but I know my own ground.”

“You have a name,” she said. “I should know it if I keep paying you to scare yourself.”

He grunted and then, reluctantly, gave it away. “Lev. Like the lion, my grandmother told me, but I never saw one up here that wasn’t on a tacky flag.”

“Lady,” she said, and he glanced over like she had told him a joke and he wanted to decide if laughing at it would make them both feel better or worse.

The run around the point took longer today because the swell had a slant to it, shouldering the hull with the soft insistence of someone who believes they deserve to cut the line. The concrete teeth of the old place showed themselves in a yawn, gray and green and gummy with plant life, and when Lev held off for the drop he kept his mouth shut, which Lady appreciated. Words went odd in air like this. They got thin and too wide-cornered.

She went ashore with the small jump of someone not aiming to impress, adjusted the pack tight between her shoulder blades, and made for the seam in the rock. Up close the hum got into her ears the way a low fever does, as if the rock had swallowed a bee and the bee was still displeased. The same grease smear by the jamb, the same hairline grit where the door had eaten a little of itself out of habit, and when she put her palm to it she felt a vibration like the one you get when you put your hand on the back of a cat that has seen something out the window you will never see as well.

She did not fight the lock because she was not foolish enough to believe she could do it faster or quieter than the person who used it. Instead she walked the seam of the cliff, nose leading her the way it had led her to patches of morels, and found the vent by scent before she saw it. Air came out in a way that was irregular but not random, a dragon trying to hold in fume, and the louver had been painted a color that wanted to be rock and only got halfway there. One of the screws had a less satisfying bite than its brothers, and when she took the wire from her pack and twisted a loop through the slat she could get just enough leverage with rope and muscle to see the grate quiver. It had been maintained, which told her something she already knew but liked hearing again because confirmation had its own warmth in a cold place.

She didn’t force it. The tide talked to her ankles. The algae on the lower lip of the vent glistened like a fresh scar and she marked it with the edge of a shell so lightly you would not see the change unless you returned with eyes for that exact line. She rigged a whisper-bell with the wire, three smooth stones, and a patience that wasn’t performative. If the door opened, or if anyone roughed the louver, the stones would kiss each other and a slip of copper against stone would make a sound that wasn’t natural here. Hunters and gardeners both know that sound is a border and a signal, and she wanted a border more than she wanted an open door for now.

She moved along the shelf until the rock cupped her, and there the sea had gnawed a little cave into what she had assumed was only bunker. It was not big. It held the sort of dark that had been learned, not born. When she crouched and played the flashlight across the stone she saw where human work had smoothed what sea work had made, a pencil’s correction over a child’s drawing. The beam of light bent on fog, and she shut it off because that taught more than brightness did. In the dim she could smell the cleaner they had used inside and the salt that had tried to fight it and lost, and somewhere under that the faintest thread of meat turned old.

Her phone fought the rock and won a single bar. She used it to check the hour and to pretend she was a person who had normal things to do, and then the phone made its insect rattle. A new post on the blog had wriggled into being, and she almost didn’t read it because she had a superstition about letting other people’s words into your mouth when you were trying to do something clean. She read anyway because superstition was a luxury and practicality demanded knowing which way the latest barbs were facing.

He had written a small sermon about purity again, a knot of sentences tied so tight they cut the fingers of anyone who tried to pick them apart. It lay there, a sticky philosophy, and buried near the bottom was a brag he’d thrown like a stone at a stranger’s porch: some things the sea can’t wash away, some lines the water draws and redraws and never crosses. He was in love with that idea. He thought of himself as one of those places. She closed her eyes and let the brag sit on her tongue until it diluted enough that she could swallow without gagging.

Movement on the horizon interrupted her internal catalog of tools and lies. A figure against the sky, then two gulls skewing around it like punctuation, and she pressed herself into the shadow of the cave without dramatics because making yourself smaller is a thing a body remembers from before brains got so loud. The figure moved like a man used to measuring his steps differently depending on the surface. He didn’t so much place his feet as let them turn to hands when needed, toes spreading where they could find grip, and her breath shortened on reflex. He wore a jacket two sizes too big in a particular way; not fashion, not thrift, but because it hid angles he didn’t want seen, and his hair had that almost-wet look of someone who had just rinsed his head in cold water and didn’t own a towel.

He did not go straight to the door. He circled the shelf where she had planted her little bell, and if he saw anything he didn’t grant her the courtesy of noticing. He stopped at the vent, put his face close, and took in a breath you would think was meant for scenting her, but was more likely a ritual of his—smell your den, claim it with your own nose. He reached to the grate with his right hand and, thank every quiet god, his fingers landed on the wrong slat for the wire. He tapped twice, some code of his own, and then he moved to the door, nudged the grease smear as if to say hello, and pressed his palm to the metal in the space where her cheek had been earlier. The keypad had been cleverly disguised as an old plate for a long-gone handle, but you could hear the soft insect beep underneath when he thumbed three numbers with a speed that spoke of practice, then a pause, then two more. She counted in her head and hated that the sea took the smallest notes from her even when it was gentle. Three, pause, two. That was something, not enough to stake a life on, but something.

Everything in her wanted to stay hidden and let him vanish through the door like a fish into a shadow, but the part of her that had had to deal with moose eating her starts and hail flattening her peas stepped forward a half-inch for her and made her look with her full face instead of out of the corner of her eye. He had a bag over his shoulder—not canvas, something slicker—and when he moved the weight of it changed the way he held himself and she saw the outline of something not quite tool, not quite toy. A jack, maybe, modified; a lurid metal with too much polish for a shy object. He carried it like a man who had found a machine that let his hands lie about what they could do.

Inside, the hum deepened, and she felt it in her sternum, heard it make a bowl of her chest. She slipped back until the small cave held her like a partial hand and she did not move until the door thunked shut and the rock took on the sound of being watched by absence. Then, stomach in her throat, she pulled her pack higher and went the way nobody went who cared about their ankles or their living. If he had a door, he had a second, and an old place like this had had to let air and wires and men in from the sea before there were roads for them. She found the seam under the overhang by sitting and feeling with her palms because sight is a braggart and touch tells the truth more often, and when her fingers found the lip they also found the metal of a latch whose bolts had wept their rust down into a pretty pattern a gull had shat on.

The rope did the heavy work, but it was the knowledge of angles that helped more. She used the wire as a tourniquet and the leverage of her whole self, thighs and shoulders the way you use them when prying a rootball from the earth that wants to hold it, and when the latch gave it wasn’t obedient so much as it was bored. The second door jerked, a breath you could mistake for the sea, and she slid into a throat of concrete that smelled like old rain and the stubborn aftertaste of solvents. There was light down the hall from an old fixture someone had manhandled a new bulb into, and the quality of it made her think of surgeries performed in films made with money, all clean and unforgiving and not as generous as sunlight even when it was trying.

She moved like a person who had spent a long time stopping herself from moving. Her hands wanted to test everything and she told them no. Her mouth wanted to form words and she told it to be the mouth of a fish. The hum here in the throat of the place was a skin on her skin, and when she got to the first room she almost laughed because of course the floor had been painted red long ago and of course someone had kept up the paint in wobbly patches that didn’t match. The table in the middle wasn’t a table, not really; it was a platform with rails that could hold a body down or hold a machine steady, and on the wall a rack of tools waited the way real tools do, unashamed of their work. There was a pair of Hi-Lift jacks modified with welded collars, a set of pulleys braced into a hardpoint above with a care that told of hours, a harness whose straps had been stitched by someone who watched videos and then taught their hands to do the thing well enough for their purposes. Gloves hung on pegs inside-out, and someone had written numbers in marker on the backs of them like a person writing children’s names inside hats.

She did not vomit, because what was here was not gore. It was intent laid out like a lesson. It was worse because of that. On a side table sat a bottle of pine cleaner and a stack of terry cloth rags, pried from hotel rooms one by one if the little tags half-torn off them were any sign, and next to that was a pile of those blue shoe covers you put on when you’re told to imagine you are tidy. She took pictures. The phone’s shutter noise was a mosquito she battered dead between forefinger and thumb, and she turned off the sound like a person remembering the kettle when it had almost boiled over.

The next room was smaller and had a chair and a desk that had started life in a school, the top scarred with compass-stabbed constellations and the outline of a heart someone had written a name inside and then tried to sand away. On the desk were printouts of his blog posts, lines underlined with a pen that pressed hard enough to score the cheap paper. There was a map with pushpins. There were pins at clinics, at a bus stop, on the Park Strip where the vigil had been. There were pins on the coast that corresponded to places the tide never quite reached, and she ran her finger along a row of them and felt the prickle you get when you imagine someone else's mind as a cupboard with each shelf labeled wrong on purpose. A photograph had been pinned to the corner of the map; it was a close-up of lichen that looked like a handprint, green and small and lovely, and written in a tidy, almost shy block print at the bottom were the words: the world is made of maps.

Her breath had married her heart to become a choir by the time she heard the sound of someone entering a space he thought was safe. It wasn’t the door because the hum ate that. It was the sound of a human breath released because it did not have to pretend anymore, the small wheeze of relief that is the first indulgence people allow themselves when they are alone. She didn’t think. She moved. The corner with the shelves full of boxes labeled with ordinary lies—Nails, Chargers, Tape—had a little wedge of shadow behind it, and she made herself into the body that fit there. He came into the room with the accuracy of someone whose body was an argument he had finally won. He set the bag down with care and cooed at it the way men who think they don’t need to apologize coo at dogs. His hair was darker than it had been in the light. His shoulders had that rented look again. His hands—uncanny—were both elegant and brutal, the fingers longer than they should have been if you believed in shoulds, the nails thickened like hooves that had decided to attempt hands, and over both fists he wore something that looked made and not bought, a brace that ran from palm to forearm, slick with the suggestion of hydraulics too cheap to be that but making a show anyway.

He hummed tunelessly, the kind of sound a child makes when offered freedom in a room not meant for them. He opened the bag and lifted the thing inside like a priest shows a relic to a congregation. It was a jack. It was a press. It was something in between that borrowed the name of a car’s emergency and made it into an intention. He ran his thumb along a seam and then set it aside and—this nearly did her in—adjusted one of the pegs on the glove rack so all the pairs would hang at the same height. Then he turned to the map, stood so close his breath moved the pushpins, and tapped the Park Strip with a knuckle.

He spoke aloud, and his voice was younger than she had imagined. The blog had smoothed it into granite, but there were still edges of boy in the way certain consonants rode his teeth. “They light candles like their grandmothers,” he said, and then he laughed at himself for saying that out loud because saying things out loud makes them more concrete in rooms where concrete holds everything up. “They want me to be afraid of wax.” He wasn’t talking to himself so much as he was narrating to someone he imagined would hear. If she had been foolish, she would have thought he meant her. He meant the world. He meant the invisible jury he had always believed was listening and always thought he would beat by being louder.

She did not know how long she stood like the shadow of a yes while he did the small business of someone readying himself to be clean for later filth. When he reached for the rag and the pine cleaner she slipped like a fish that had only ever been water, and she thought, as she pulled herself back into the throat of the place, that fear is a light, not a rope. It shows you where; it does not tie you. The latch she had coaxed into coughing earlier tried to bite her hand on the way out, and she swore at it like a person and then laughed, silent, because it was ridiculous and laughter made room in her chest for things like air.

Outside, the sky had dimmed in a way northern skies do when they are practicing being righteous. The tide had come up in the way of a person approaching from across a room. There was more conversation in the water now. The little stones she had rigged at the vent lay exactly how she had left them and that meant he had not yet touched that mouth to the world today, and she made a decision that would either feel smart later or be the thing people pointed to when they said: she had guts but not judgement. She took the coil of wire and she fed it into the slit between door and jamb like a snake refusing to be disappointed, and she bent it hard and twisted, making a kink that would catch in the narrow space where latch and plate met. It was a child’s trick, the kind schoolkids use to lock bathroom stalls as a prank, and doing childish things to a man who had built himself a theology of knives felt like a kind of medicine she could administer without a license.

She backed away and left the coil’s tail tucked under a piece of drift. Lev was a patience-smudge out on the water, and she could see in the way his shoulders held the wheel that he wanted to curse at her but had decided superstition against it. She made the shelf before her ankles could make this their story, and when she slid over the last barnacled lip the sea made a slap at her boot as if to remind her which force in the world mattered and which did not. In the boat, she let her breath be obscene. Lev did not ask; he looked at her hands and at the wet mark on the knee of her jeans and he asked by not asking, which is a gift.

“He was there,” she said finally, and Lev’s mouth went smaller. “I went in,” she said, and his mouth went smaller still until it was barely a mouth at all. “There’s no blood, just tools. There’s a map.” She described what she’d seen, and his eyes did the thing decent people’s do when you pull back a curtain they have always stepped around but never quite admitted was there.

He took the boat in a little wide because the water had woken to something. At the harbor he helped her up with none of the performative chivalry he had cattail-laughed at last week when some tourist offered his arm to a woman who had eight decades and a halibut under hers. Before she could go he told her, strangely formal, that he had a daughter in Sitka who liked women and had a laugh like a loose hinge, and that if this Brendan breathed the same air as his daughter he would net that air and hand it back empty. She nodded, and they shook hands like men who had made a deal they meant to keep when someone asked them about it with a Bible on a table.

Havel met her halfway down the dock. He had no sunglasses today, which meant he knew anybody who saw his eyes would be the kind of person who would tell him he looked like what he was. She showed him the pictures in the shadow of a stack of crab pots and he said the words he had to say—chain of custody, warrants, teams—but he also said something softer that had all the heft of a prayer said by a man who didn’t do that: Thank you. He texted the pictures elsewhere, and his phone began to make the angry noises of machines that have been told to go now and cannot walk and resent that.

“Don’t go home alone,” he said in a careful voice that had practiced since yesterday at being both directive and respectful and managed clumsy with both. “We’re going to hit it. Today, if I can convince anybody that we don’t need a committee to decide whether a door is a door.”

“If you wait for a committee,” she said, and he held up a palm, smiling a little with the hard-smile of men who know irony won’t make a dent this deep.

He went, and she went, and between them the air held the weight of two people having made the same promise without asking the other one how much anyone intended to pay for it. Back in her truck, the phone had done the indecent thing of letting in the blog as if nothing else in the world were happening. The latest post upended her equilibrium not because of the words—those were the same tired sermon— but because of the picture he’d chosen to go with it. It was a rock shelf with a lichen handprint, yes, that part was his little flag, but in the left top corner, if you knew what you were looking at, was the smallest sliver of galvanized wire, its curl neat as a schoolgirl’s. She held the phone closer and then farther and she let a curse sit on her lip like a small bird.

You had to be in a place to take the picture. He had been at the door after she left, and if he had found her wire and photographed it and then still not removed it, she had to believe that had been vanity, not mercy. She was not even a player to him. She was a correspondent. He was in love with narrating to her. She wanted a different kind of romance. The comments under the post did their usual, the antiphonal call-and-response of praise and disgust and the performative genetic tracing some people deploy when faced with an enemy they can’t punch, and then buried under it all, a little blue dot, and her finger was already pitching into the private inbox before she had decided whether to speak.

He had written to her, not the world. To her: I heard your stones kiss. You have small hands. You tried to jam my door. That was fun. I used to do that to my brothers’ rooms when they were smaller than me. We are the same, you and I, except your hands are dirty and mine are clean. Come see again. Bring me something alive to look at. I’m tired of this kind of life.

Her first temptation was to write nothing because sometimes the only way to deny someone air is to close your own throat, but she had never believed in the practice of starving yourself to starve a monster. She wrote: I’ll bring you a plant. You can watch it die while you talk, and maybe you’ll feel something smart enough to sit down on. Then she put the phone upside down on the seat like a child you didn’t want to look at yet, and she drove.

Home breathed around her in the way of a place that is not a fortress but is also not a lie. Olia had left another note. Nik had fixed the latch on the greenhouse because the rooster had learned a new trick. Somebody had put three jars of lake trout on the porch with a plain old pencil scrawl that said: for your troubles, which made her bark a laugh that wasn’t altogether kind at the idea that troubles were something you paid with fish. She liked the world for offering anyway. She bought two minutes with a kettle and Rhea with her voice on the phone in the background ordering someone to breathe slowly and count to five out loud, and when Rhea came back on line she sounded like a woman who had just ridden a wave to sand and was embarrassed to have squeaked.

“You’re in one piece,” Rhea said. “I was going to call you but the day swallowed me.”

“I was in,” Lady said. “It is what we thought and then some, because thinking does not prepare you for seeing a jack that looks like a christening.”

Rhea went quiet and then swore in a language she had inherited from a grandmother and only used when the sharpness of English felt tired. “They’re going to go,” she said. “They’re going to do the Things. There will be a helicopter and men with vests and someone who can spell federal but not care where the word falls. You won’t be with them. Promise me.”

Lady wanted to say yes. She wanted to say yes for Rhea the way children want to say yes to mothers in grocery stores. Instead she told the truth in a different way, which was to say: “He took a picture of my wire and posted it. He wants me to come back. It makes him careless.”

Rhea made a sound like a pot lid rattled against a boil and then took in a breath that had a discipline to it that ought to be taught to soldiers. “Careless and proud is how people trip and crack their teeth on their own intentions. I don’t like you playing the trip.”

“If he thinks he’s the gravity he wrote about, then he forgets about wind,” Lady said. “Wind changes.”

She hung up before Rhea could ask for something she couldn’t give. Then she made decisions the way she liked to—by filling her hands so her head would follow. She took the little specimen pot with a seedling borage in it from the sill. Borage was a plant she trusted, all prickles and blue star flowers and a taste that made you believe cucumbers were cousins. It handled neglect poorly and thrived on attention like some people she had loved and couldn’t have. If he wanted her to bring something alive, she would bring a plant that made bees ecstatic and added a brightness to soup and might die in a room with that hum, which felt like truth packaged small enough to set down on a table.

She fed the rooster corn to shut him up. She put the coil of wire back into the pack and added a handful of nails like punctuation, because sometimes ending a sentence is a kindness. She took a roll of flagging tape too, the hot pink kind used to mark trees for cutting, because she was tired of pretending subtlety was the only way to win a game when the other player had turned neon into a sacrament. She put the borage in a waxed box and cushioned it with newspaper that had an article about the town’s Fourth of July parade, and then she moved through her house touching the things that did not need touching simply so her hand could know what it was saying goodbye to for a few hours.

At the dock Lev looked at the box and raised an eyebrow that was a whole conversation. She told him, slowly, that she might need him to do something stupid today and he said, with a gentlemanly irritation that reminded her of old men in old hats, that he had expected to do something stupid from the second she had told him her name. They went out. The water had put on a better dress for afternoon, but the wind had broken a heel and it was listing. The clouds in the west were gathering in a way that meant someone with more faith would have stayed home and made soup. She showed Lev the picture on her phone and he said nothing for a long time and then: “Showboat. Maybe I take up whittling and make him a little stage.”

On the shelf, the wire still held its cunning smile. The hum hit her bones like an old song and she let it only make background for what came next. She set the borage down on the flat of the concrete where the grease smear caught the light like a wink. She dusted the leaves with the barest kiss of water from the bottle in her pack because she could not show up with something alive and not take care of it even if she meant to weaponize its need. She stepped back and dropped the flagging tape at the base and let the wind slap it against the rock into a little dance that would make her angry if she had not chosen it. Then she went to the cave’s second door, the one she had taught her hands to unlatch, and again she made the latch bored.

Inside the hum had a temper now, muttering in a loop like a tired man with a beef. She kept left because buildings have instincts and left felt like the instinct of a thing built to keep its soft places to itself. She moved past the red floor and the rack of gloves and the plank that was not a table and into a room she had not seen yet because her nerve had failed earlier at the whisper of footsteps and a breath freed. It was a storage space and a shrine. Here were boxes with labels that had lied about nails and tape but now told the truth about what they wanted: Gauze, Lume, Zip. Here were bottles of something thick that had not wanted to be apart of this story but were because someone had stolen them from a clinic supply room and had written Thank you with a heart on a donation jar there on their way out. Here, too, was a stack of small notebooks bound in cardboard the color of dust, and her hand went to one without permission. Lists. Names. Dates. The neatness of a sociable madness.

She had the book inside her jacket without remembering the movement, and then the soft fingers of panic tickled the back of her neck because she was doing criminal acts in the lair of a man who believed law was a kind of bad joke. She put the book back, breathe, take out her phone, photograph the first three pages like a thief with an eye for consequences, and slide the book to look as if it had not been touched because some people see touch like a bruise even when skin looks flawless.

Something changed in the sound, and she knew before she thought that the big door had opened and then jammed and then a man with hands like motives had met her wire with a laugh. Her body went into flight without consulting the committee of her thoughts. The hall felt shorter and longer at once. The red floor, the map, the rack of gloves. The side door. If he had jammed the big door only long enough to tell himself a story about idiots, then she had a window. She slid into the throat and the latch scraped her knuckles into a sting she did not mind, and when she spilled onto the rocks the air hit her with its wet cloth and she drank it like soup.

He did not come out the second door immediately, which meant he wanted the theater of confronting her where he believed his words would carry best. The borage stood where she had set it, the flagging tape doing its little pink suicide in the wind, and the big door had a new mouthful of wire protruding like a knife you throw for show. He would get it free in two minutes if he had any patience, less if he didn’t. Lev’s boat was a few heartbeats away, and she started toward the shelf’s edge in a gait that would look to someone in love with this man like cowardice and would appear to someone in love with her like sense.

The door didn’t so much open as shrug the wire off and step over it. He came out with the bag on his shoulder again and the particular loose set of his body that said he was ready to dance the wrong kind. He saw her and he did what she had counted on him doing: he smiled because he had made the world into a mirror that smiled when he wanted it to. He glanced at the borage and tore his smile at an angle too, a new trick, and he shook his head a small shake like a teacher disappointed in a child who had brought the wrong book to class.

“I said bring me something alive,” he said, and he had put on a voice for her like a coat, the one he thought would make this a scene for him and a story for her. “That’s… good. I thought you would bring something with a pulse.”

She kept her voice as plain as bread. “You don’t get to have both,” she said. “You can have a plant or you can have an animal. You’ve been picking wrong.”

He considered for the briefest of ticks, a dog dumb with a new bell, and then he laughed. The laugh did not like having to carry this much. He shifted the bag slightly and the shadow of whatever was inside drew a line across his chest in a way that carried information she filed away under words that would come later when her heart wasn’t pounding against the dictionary. He did something she hadn’t predicted: he crouched and pinched the tape between thumb and forefinger and stopped it from dancing. Then he let it go and watched it whip back into motion with a satisfaction that was almost childlike except for the disgust that came immediately after for having enjoyed something so simple.

“You came into my house,” he said, and this time his voice had almost no dressing on it at all. “That’s rude.”

“You came into mine,” she said. “I considered leaving you cookies. I reconsidered.”

He licked his lips in a way that would have read as nervous in a different person and here read as a ritual. He reached out to touch the borage leaf and she saw the exact second when the tiny hairs on the plant bit his skin back and his mouth did a small and exquisite disgust. He wiped his fingers on his pants the way a boy wipes his hands after touching something he has been told is icky, and then he grinned with too many teeth. “It tastes like cucumber,” she said, and he said he didn’t like cucumber, which told her something she didn’t need and yet loved having.

Lev’s boat bumped the shelf and then backed off because he was not going to make a fool of himself by running the prop onto some drama. He had a boat hook half-hidden and an indifference on his face that would get him into heaven if anyone was keeping track. Brendan—Brendan?—turned his head toward the water with the same disdain he had turned toward the plant and Lady saw, with a clarity that hurt, how much he wanted to perform for her and not for a stranger. He was a cheap actor in an expensive suit, and it had always worked before. She was not his audience and she was also the only audience he wanted.

She did not wait for his words to shape into something he would use to hold her. She moved, the kind of movement you learn from doors that stick and dogs that bolt. She put the borage between them because she was perverse and because the small gesture made a part of her relax, and she reached the lip just as Lev brought the bow in the distance of a breath away. She made the jump her boots had practiced and the boat dipped and Lev swore once and then eased the boat out and the water took them with more kindness than they deserved.

On shore, Havel’s phone had decided to be a trumpet instead of a phone and he was saying words people say at boats when boats can’t hear them. She sat on the dock and let her breath normal out, and she felt the hum in her teeth even here, like she had swallowed a piece of that place and would have to pass it like a bad pearl. Havel crouched beside her and by the set of his jaw she could tell the door was about to learn a new word called warrant.

“He saw you,” Havel said, which was unnecessary, which in its unnecessaryness made it attempt tenderness and fail, which in its failure managed to be something like comfort anyway.

“He likes attention,” she said. “He’ll wait for yours. I wouldn’t give him too much, but I would give him a lot of men.” She smiled and it came out wrong and she let it sit there like a weed you pull later when you have better shoes on.

The borage sat on the shelf by the door of a man who had made himself into a sermon, and she loved it for being witness. If it survived an afternoon of that hum she would go back for it. If it didn’t, she would scatter its seeds like a rude kindness and make a handful of blue stars in some other crack in this hard and breathing world. Havel’s men moved like men making movies. Lev spat in the water again and muttered that if these boys put one more thing heavy on his dock he would put them over his knee. The blog did not post for three hours, then for five, then for seven, and that absence was more eloquent than all his polished hurt had ever been.

Evening smudged itself around the edges of the day with its particular northern incompetence at finishing the task. Olia came by with her sleeves rolled and a pie she claimed to have bought when anyone with eyes could see was her crust and her stubbornness. They ate with their legs up and their boots left by the door as if dirt had a border it respected, and they did not talk about men with hands like questions. They cared for the small things—how the cucumbers had forgiven them, how the rooster had watched the men on the porch with a disdain that implied a previous career. Later, beneath the laugh and the pie, with the ravens pulling the day’s leftovers into their pockets by the ditch, Lady let herself stand at the edge of the garden and make the sort of vow you do not say out loud because the saying of it would turn it brittle. She would go again if the door opened. She would plant where he had salted. She would make noise when silence helped him and she would erect fence when noise did, and she would find the part of him that could be predicted, because everything grows along a pattern even when it thinks it has invented itself.

Wind came in from the water with the sourness of kelp lifted and left too long in a bucket, and by midmorning Lady could taste weather behind her teeth the way she could taste iron in her well when the pump coughed. Lev texted without preamble, just the picture of a gray hull with a stripe and men with hands on their belts looking like boys at a swimming hole trying to decide who would be brave first. Havel’s message followed with fewer words than a man in his position was used to having to make do with: here we go, stay clear. She put the phone in her back pocket so she wouldn’t keep looking at it every fifteen seconds, locked her door with the same small, mindful motion she used to set a trap for slugs, and hit the road with her braid tucked under the moose-patch cap and the thermos sealed hard.

The pullout above the point was one of those places that looked invented for a postcard until the wind hit and reminded you that everything beautiful up here had hard corners you couldn’t Photoshop. Lev had already beached his old truck nose-in and was leaning on the hood, hat backward and face rinsed clean by a mood he wasn’t naming. The boat he’d left in its slip because there were people with federal letters on their jackets now, and a man with letters on his jacket doesn’t like surprises that smell like diesel and honest rope. He handed her his binoculars without comment and she raised them to her eyes and felt the instant of vertigo that comes with dragging something far into your face and making it near whether it wants to be or not.

You could see the shelf like the lip of a bitten mouth, the seam of the door that had learned to look like rock, the smear of grease that caught the light the way some people catch blame. A line of men ghosted along the upper path in that strange crouch men adopt when they’re trying to be both large and small, and a pair of them took knees that would complain later and pointed guns at a door that had no respect for guns because it had been built to shrug off worse. At the same time a second contingent came in by a little rubber boat along a line Lev would never approve and he muttered something under his breath as if correcting their form might change the tide. Havel wasn’t in her glass, but she knew his walk already, the way he kept his torso straight and his head moving as if he might have a bird on his shoulder he didn’t trust to sit still.

The first noise wasn’t noise at all, it was a change in the hum. It deepened and broadened like a foghorn being lowered into a cellar, and she saw the men turn their heads in unison like geese and hated the instinct that had them all offering their throats to the same frequency. The wire at the door flicked and lay down, a meaningless fish, and then glove-hands were in it, tool-hands, hands that had trained and thought they could shame any lock by looking at it long enough. The sea went still the way animals go still when they’re a second from doing something they’ve never done in front of you before.

She couldn’t see the moment where the door gave up pretending. One second there was rock and line and the next there was a slice with depth, the darkness had temperature, and men moved through it like swimmers slipping into water not of their own making. Lev swore softly when one of them knocked the pot with the borage and set it rocking its small planet of dirt, and Lady kept herself from the upward, stupid motion her hands wanted by pinning her forearms against her ribs. She did not need to see her plant righted from this distance to believe it would forgive her if she came back with half of what was promised.

They were too slow and too quick, both, which is how careful looks under pressure when the audience is the sea. A rope trailed, unnecessary and therefore essential, and going in twos they vanished into our made cave with the hubris we punish boys for and then ask men to practice. The hum climbed and then stopped. It didn’t fade. It didn’t bleed away polite. It quit like a man slamming a phone down. A bandwidth of silence opened and in it she could hear gulls arguing three coves away and the tiny, triumphant click of a beetle in the grass between her boots. Lev said, not loud enough to reach anyone but her, that a sound that stops like that has a hand in it, and she nodded like he could see her without the binoculars hiding half her face.

They came out with things that were not Brendan. Boxes labeled with lies and carried as if they were heavy because the lie said so, the hydraulic thing that had looked like a jack and wore its beauty like a wound, the map with its pins and its tidy, stapled corners. A man held up the rack of gloves like a fish too obscene to triumph over and Havel gestured with his two fingers—down, down, you’re not on stage—and the man put it down with an embarrassed care that made him human again. A minute later another human came out with his hand pressed to the place under his ribs where panic lives, and Lady thought: there is a room we didn’t see, a breath you don’t get unless you step somewhere that’s remembering something it shouldn’t.

No Brendan. No figure with borrowed shoulders and hands like a mistake a god made on a Friday. She could tell from the set of Havel’s head when he finally came out that the pivot had hurt. You build your speech for cameras around a man you think you will bag and then you have to chisel it back down to evidence and process, and no man likes to eat that meal cold. He stood there with his mouth not yet composed, and the wind took his next sentence and tossed it up like chaff and he let it go. He made a call with one of those phones that look like they could be thrown at a bear and survive and then he tilted his head as if to listen to the sea like she did, getting religion late.

By afternoon the place looked less like myth and more like what it was—a ruin with electric organs, a bad idea someone had maintained past the point where its badness should have been obvious. White vans butted their noses in like goats, men in coveralls with day-glo stripes went in and out with arms full of heavy and came back out lighter and lighter until they had taken from the place everything they believed was valuable. Lev leaned on his hood again and watched the road like his daughter might come around the corner just now and require a story, and Lady kept the binoculars to her eyes until the rims made marks on her face that would surprise her later when she looked by mistake in a mirror and saw a woman who had been looking too hard.

The blog stayed quiet and the quiet wasn’t clean. It was the sort of quiet a man makes when he’s grinning into a mirror trying on other people’s teeth. The entire town adjusted its shoulders by half an inch and there were more dogs tied by doors than there had been yesterday, and the supermarket was out of batteries by two. Rhea called long enough to say she’d been sent a memo with bolded words like stay vigilant and personal safety and a list of social work phrases that tried to make carefulness into a coat people would actually wear. She said a man with bare feet had walked through the lobby leaving prints that made the receptionist cross herself and then pet the place on the counter where she’d set down the clipboard as if the clipboard were a cat. He hadn’t stopped, had turned at the elevators like a man reconsidering a party and left like a tide you only notice after it has scoured the beach clean.

Evening began without the blog and it made her itch, made the small hairs at the nape of her neck stand up like a field in wind, and when the sky refused, as ever, to close its eye, she drove back to the point because sometimes you must check your fence more often than the animal visits. Lev came with because he was a man willing to stand next to a thing that made him angry if that meant he didn’t have to stand next to it later with regret. The shelf was a mouth again, shut this time, and the borage had done what borage always tries to do and leaned in the direction of light, which meant three of its leaves had gotten burned into a little wryness where they’d brushed the metal. She touched the leaf and the plant forgave her faster than she had earned.

On the seam at shin-height, where only a person very close would see, someone had pasted a compass rose cut out of a cereal box and painted its points with some chemical green that held onto light too long after sunset. It wasn’t just cute, it wasn’t just a joke. The points had been sharpened until they might cut your finger if you were stupid enough to touch them hard, and in the center, where any mapmaker would have put their pretty insignia, there was a small circle in silver marker with a cross through it. The cross drifted exactly a hair off true if she held it up against the sky and the old radar tower’s ghost of a line. It was a message that knew its audience and wanted her to know that knowing.

They stood there until the cold pushed up their pant legs and made itself a citizen of their bones. Lev said he had a thermos and lied, because what he had was a bottle, and they shared it and talked about herring and about how ducks sometimes end up with fishhooks in their feet and will peck at your hands when you hold them anyway because that’s just what panic does with kindness.
